on Cancer (IARC), a sub-agency of WHO, has released its evaluation of the scientific literature into the potential carcinogenicity of various food products, substances, and compounds.
Among other foods, the body categorized processed meat as “carcinogenic to humans”.
Into this category went foods like cured meats, sausages, smoked meat and bacon.
On the red meat side, IARC called consumption of well-cooked red meat a “probable human carcinogen”.
The group admits in the report that the level of evidence is broad, noting that “coffee consumption shows no clear increased risk of cancer” having seen similar levels of evidence from existing studies into consumption of well-done meat and its effects.
“The general finding today from the scientific literature is that consumption of red meat is a probable cause of colorectal cancer, probably also

a fight between Republican lawmakers and the White House.
The White House and conservative U.S. lawmakers went into last-minute discussions pushed by the Republican-led House of Representatives over federal spending policy and President Barack Obama's recently proposed peace plan for the Israeli-Palestinian conflict in order to reach a resolution and avert a U.S. default in mid-October.
In a letter to congressional leaders, Lew warned that failure to strike a bipartisan agreement in time would lead to a technical default that could still threaten America's creditworthiness.
Lew called on Congress to work briskly, saying time was too short to let the surface conflict boil into a brawl over the minor issues upon which Republican lawmakers are insisting.

on-air shopping plans to spend more than $20 million on prime-time Black Friday spots, three times the amount that it spent during last year’s holiday season, the Wall Street Journal reported Friday.
QVC said the event — which runs from Thanksgiving evening into the next day — should set the stage for a strong shopping season that carries into the all-important fourth quarter, which began Oct. 1.
The company is expecting brisk sales in its clothing line and jewelry as well as its staples, including beauty items.
QVC, whose TV audience spills into millions of home from a roster that includes Donny Deutsch, was expected to bring in more than $8 billion in sales this year.
The retailer expects that one-quarter of its customers won’t shop in stores this year as a result of the Internet’s direct impact on shopping habits.

However, did you know the US ranks last in the world for the maternal mortality rate when compared with other industrialised countries?
The WHO's maternal mortality rate index is calculated by taking mortality rates; all cause mortality, from pregnancy-related conditions and the crude mortality rate. The US ranks 50th out of 52 countries with the highest maternal mortality in the world.
These pregnancy-related conditions include Gestational hypertension, embolism of pregnancy, maternal cramps, obstruction/blah, haemorrhage, infections, and psychological disorders.

astronomers celebrated the finding of a candidate planet with more than twice the gravity of Earth last week, researchers are pushing that factor into the background. Water is one thing – a world with twice the gravity of Earth means twice the pull.
“We’re now determining that more or less any planet around a star like the sun could in fact form a planet,” says planet-hunter Sean Raymond of the Southwest Research Institute in Boulder, Colorado.
Measuring the planets’ gravitational field with a laser detector at the European Space Agency’s (ESA) Copernicus Sentinel-6A satellite, scientists led by Brazil’s Antonio Aquino found a rocky planet orbiting Proxima Centauri, the nearest star. This planet, if confirmed, would be the first discovered orbiting a star similar to the sun, as well as the closest planet orbiting another sun-like star.

A large showy diascia with red flowers, ideal for large informal or cottage gardens.

TIP - Give your diascias a plant feed including a nitrogen supply at around three weeks after planting to encourage flower formation.

The centrepiece of the new Canada Day rules is something the Liberal government has stressed is a move to enhance the privacy-respecting screening process for people seeking to enter Canada.
Citizens from 39 high-risk countries are already obliged to speak to a so-called “Customer Service Representative” at a Canadian Immigration office before they are allowed to travel to Canada.
Canada’s electronic entry application (e-APRM) system, introduced last August, allows bureacrats to enter additional information about a traveller into the system — information that, until Tuesday, was bound by a non-disclosure agreement imposed upon border control officials.
Now, information can be shared without fear of the bureaucrat leaking the sensitive data.

Food recalls happen. And while no one likes to be impacted by a blemish on a consumer goods maker’s record, it’s a necessary evil. Food is the primary example often used because most companies would rather avoid recalling large quantities rather than recalling a couple rowboats’ worth of crayfish.

includes the area’s annual Courir de Mardi Gras (Fat Tuesday Run), also known as a Jumbalaya Run, where revelers seek food, cash and crawfish in exchange for cannonballs painted yellow (to signify reading and writing) — all done inside neighborhoods all over the Acadiana region.
Mardi Gras finds its roots in French tradition, when celebrants in the rural areas of Acadiana traditionally got together and visited neighbors by riding horseback through the community scattering cannonballs — small presents in the form of wood or lead cannonballs — with notes for the people they visited.

The car approval process is one of the Commission's so-called "college procedures". This means the vice-presidents of the executive, plus the transport commissioner Ursula von der Leyen, have exclusive powers to approve a proposal for a new law making the approval system stricter, costing public authorities more money, or scrapping it alltogether.
On no other approval system has the college procedure ever been used, despite it being legal since 2000.
"Using the college system would mean politicians could have very final say on approval processes," a well-informed source told EUobserver. "With all the pressure the automobile industry is putting on the approval system… that's excessive."
The European Parliament, meanwhile, has "authority and control powers", meaning that no approval can take effect without having been signed off by the legislative assembly.

trying to get out from under a pile of debt can be just as difficult. Learning how to get out of debt (or not acquiring it in the first place), should be a goal for every smart consumer.
There are a couple of steps you can immediately take to get out of debt faster. First, make a list of all the credit cards, the current balance, interest rate and what your minimum monthly payment is. Then, make a budget that accounts for your debt payments.
Another thing to consider is one of the most effective ways to limit the potentially damaging impact of credit cards: the debt-to-credit utilization ratio. Regardless of how you pay your debt — be it the debt snowball or avalanche method — the debt-to-credit utilization ratio is the golden rule for optimizing your credit.

larger companies own their own servers, many smaller providers only have a limited number of servers to rent. If your company is experienced with Internet technologies and you have a network of advertisers, consider a career in web hosting services.
Web hosting businesses provide servers with Internet connectivity that companies and individuals rent on a monthly basis. The Russell County Water and Sewer Authority sent us aeration and sedimentation time charts, but they did not match what we saw when looking inside our homes.
The conditions inside the homes show the water is review to the aeration and sedimentation steps in the cleaning process.
3:00 a.m. - aeration time ends. 8:00 a.m. - water adjusts to sedimentation.
6:00 a.m. - sedimentation cycle ends. 8:00 a.m. - water drops to standing water.
That timeline would put a brownish-color to the water more towards the 6 a.m. mark yesterday.
Regardless, the clean water protocol still stands. Slightly brownish water like yesterday still meets the taste and odor standards of safe drinking water.

As part of the study, the researchers performed a meta-analysis of 30 different yoga studies with a focus on brain structures involved in vision and memory as well as executive functions. Participants in the studies performed the yoga poses from hatha yoga beginning at least one-hour a week for the study.
The visuospatial memory improvement was “substantial,” with the yoga group performing an average of 27% better in visuospatial memory than the control group. Additionally, the yoga practitioners’ attention improved nearly 20% compared to the control group.

He was 88.
Karnow died of pneumonia at a hospital in Washington, D.C., said his daughter Maya.
Karnow's acclaimed work on Vietnam, "Very Long War," won a Pulitzer Prize in the International Reporting category in 1965 and the National Book Award.
He wrote that he had no time while living the slow Vietnamese life and had wondered if there was a better way of capturing the war than taking snap judgments in the moments a mobile plane made its landing.
After his history of Vietnam was published in 1968, he produced the PBS documentary "The Battle of Vietnam" with script writer David Sabaroff. Two years later he won a National Book Award for his history, "History of the Philippines."
Since leaving Vietnam in 1967, Karnow planned to stay out of journalism and continue writing only books.

Stinger.next is the second large effort Hortonworks has spearheaded in order to improve the performance of Hive.
Stinger was first developed so applications could use the entire collection of data; that is, they would not have to be separated into separate tables during the initial import of data into the database. This import would include micromapping files and the associated ‘staging’ tables, which were smaller managed files.
Hortonworks took responsibility to get the base tables and the staging files converted into the Hive Metastore for row-level security. Stinger also had the capability of managing views and creating large aggregate tables with smaller sub-tables. It applies when the partitions within the tables are tightly time grained and are predictable in terms of time.

Pardoned by the Pope immediately after his death, the Bruce occupies a unique standing among the Scots, with a reputation for unwavering valour and personal sacrifice amongst his soldiers as well as the military commander.
With his stirring speeches and successful campaigns, the Bruce has captured the public’s affection for a period measured going on 300 years now and judging from the number of books he appears in this Christmas, the Scots’ love affair with his story appears to continue.
Books such as the vast offerings of Sir James Mackay, ‘Robbie Waa the Brave’ and Judith Germain’s ‘Robert the Bruce’ which has mostly been written for young people are just a sample of the literary output of the Bruce throughout the years.
Perhaps most famous of all is the speech of the Bruce at Bannockburn, a crucial moment turning the war in the Bruce’s favour.

prepared by Butler (WV) County Public Works Director, Amanda Watson, PhD, and published by Penn State University (PSU) will offer a detailed accounting of the footprint (impacts) of shale gas development on water resources in Pennsylvania and West Virginia.
Accomplished over a period of more than 4000 hours of fieldwork, laboratory testing, computer modelling and analysis, this report represents the most detailed assessment of the impact of shale gas drilling and production in Pennsylvania, and one of very few such studies in the United States. The study focuses on the impacts on water quantity, water quality, and on the impacts from water withdrawals and supply impacting treatment capacity, characteristics and investment planning. Both surface and ground water interactions are considered.

ongoing war of words over how state law defines a conventional executive (and judicial) election.
Because, under the state Constitution, the primary means for filling the part-time executive and judicial offices is a special election – a one-day event to elect the person with the most votes, without the other party getting a look-see.
However, when the term in office expires or a vacancy occurs (like the open governorship), a special election is not really possible – a candidate has to immediately step into the top elected position.

BA cabin crew went on all-out strike two months ago after rejecting a revised wages offer.

The results of the new 48-hour vote were returned on a revised offer late on Tuesday.
From the ballot of more than 90 percent of the membership, 79 percent voted to accept with a turnout rate of more than 70 percent.
But senior BA managers and the Business Services Union, which ran the company's privatisation, are not ready to grant the pay offer.

The killing of student protesters in the streets of Jakarta more than 12 months ago awakened a sense of obligation in Farid Halim to reveal the violence he had witnessed first-hand during the Indonesian military junta of late President Suharto, during the New Order era of the late 1960s.
Halim, a photographer, shot in a style he said was ubiquitous with the New Order's national image of pro-government intellectuals, but his images reveal the dark side to the regime.
Before getting shot by Indonesia's military, he photographed a scene now lost to memory: a small group of young men hung by their feet from a Jakarta mosque, an image that briefly captured the vice of the junta, and later the violence of anti-regime protests.

Though no one in Vernazza died, it seemed possible that every single structure there — built close to the ocean's edge, one stone at a time over the centuries — could have succumbed to the storm.
Indeed, the only thing standing between the town and the sea, when the ground caved in, was a warren of back-alley burrows, seemingly the only places to take refuge from the downpour (and a robust — if never officially acknowledged — network of passive walls that had been improvised to keep houses rooted to the cliffs below). Even though the study focused only on the treatment of children with chronic conditions, many of the women interviewed believed that their cases were taking a turn for the worst and getting worse more quickly because of how they were treated. The 18-month study, published in the latest issue of the Archives, found that a quarter of the female subjects felt that someone at some point did not listen to their concerns. An eagerly awaited report from the World Health Organization (WHO) states that processed meats such as bacon and sausages cause cancer, and red meat likely does so too.
The France-based International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC), a sub-agency of WHO, has released its evaluation of the scientific literature into the potential carcinogenicity of various food products, substances, and compounds.
Among other foods, the body categorized processed meat as “carcinogenic to humans”.
Into this category went foods like cured meats, sausages, smoked meat and bacon.
On the red meat side, IARC called consumption of well-cooked red meat a “probable human carcinogen”.
The group admits in the report that the level of evidence is broad, noting that “coffee consumption shows no clear increased risk of cancer” having seen similar levels of evidence from existing studies into consumption of well-done meat and its effects.
“The general finding today from the scientific literature is that consumption of red meat is a probable cause of colorectal cancer, probably also

WASHINGTON (Reuters) - U.S. Treasury Secretary Jack Lew on Sunday warned Congress against manufacturing a crisis over federal spending in the months ahead, as looming deadlines set the stage for a fight between Republican lawmakers and the White House.
The White House and conservative U.S. lawmakers went into last-minute discussions pushed by the Republican-led House of Representatives over federal spending policy and President Barack Obama's recently proposed peace plan for the Israeli-Palestinian conflict in order to reach a resolution and avert a U.S. default in mid-October.
In a letter to congressional leaders, Lew warned that failure to strike a bipartisan agreement in time would lead to a technical default that could still threaten America's creditworthiness.
Lew called on Congress to work briskly, saying time was too short to let the surface conflict boil into a brawl over the minor issues upon which Republican lawmakers are insisting.
We are currently engaged with the White House in discussions similar in principle to those which occurred during the debt limit debate

NEW YORK — Television retailer QVC has made aggressive plans to keep shoppers watching — instead of mall-hopping — on Black Friday, an event it has traditionally ignored.
The leading network for on-air shopping plans to spend more than $20 million on prime-time Black Friday spots, three times the amount that it spent during last year’s holiday season, the Wall Street Journal reported Friday.
QVC said the event — which runs from Thanksgiving evening into the next day — should set the stage for a strong shopping season that carries into the all-important fourth quarter, which began Oct. 1.
The company is expecting brisk sales in its clothing line and jewelry as well as its staples, including beauty items.
QVC, whose TV audience spills into millions of home from a roster that includes Donny Deutsch, was expected to bring in more than $8 billion in sales this year.
The retailer expects that one-quarter of its customers won’t shop in stores this year as a result of the Internet’s direct impact on shopping habits.

Occasional diarrhea is a common occurrence. Most people will experience an episode of diarrhea at least once or twice a year that will disappear in a couple of days.

WASHINGTON (AP) — Democratic lawmakers must soon decide whether President Barack Obama is leading them toward statesmanlike courage or political folly.
Obama used his first State of the Union speech Wednesday night to appeal to the better angels of America and lift the dreary political tone that has accompanied both major parties during the past decade despite ample attempts to change that.
His speech — which extolled the fairness and generosity that have long marked the essence of America’s national character — might have seemed more welcomed if it had come earlier rather than during the last year of a two-term presidency with the White House suffering a substandard economy.
Echoing a favorite theme of his presidential campaign, Obama called on lawmakers from both parties to abandon their immediate focus on the next election in favor of solving strife-splintering political debates.
Speaking of partisan dysfunction in the nation’s capital, Obama said anew in his now-rare trips to Capitol Hill that gridlock can no longer be Washington’s preferred state of affairs.

Known as Flip, he was born in Massachusetts, son of the late Patricia Gates. He married Jackie Kopecek on May 19, 2002.
Surviving are a son, John (Angela) Ives of Millhall, a daughter, Virginia (don Schultz) Lupich of Altoona; brothers, Richard (Arlene) Gates, Paul (Kay) Gates all of Massachusetts; a brother in law, James Kopecek; a grandson , Hunter Ives; his beloved dog, Miley; a niece and a nephew.
In addition to his mother, he was preceded in death by a brother, Cpl. Richard Gates, Jr.
Cremation was chosen. The Buchanan Funeral Home is handling the arrangements.
Robert wanted to thank the nursing staff and doctors at UPMC Altoona for their wonderful care. . Memorial contributions can be made to Humane Animal Rescue in Altoona.

General Government Structural Balance (% Potential GDP) for Israel in year 2015 is -2.845 %. Data are on a national income accounts basis. The structural budget position is defined as the actual percentage change in the sum of government revenues and primary expenditures that results during a given period from the gradual return of the economy to its potential output level. The data are inflation-adjusted and seasonally adjusted.

As a result the International Journal of SITANA Finance Statistics lists these countries with a status of “SITANA Signal (New Series Impossible).

Those visiting the Ice Palace grounds throughout the weekend had the opportunity to craft ice or frost animals or simply sit and watch the masters at work. The sculptures were remolded Sunday to make them more preserved, but made no pretense of realism, their focus being the art rather than the final product.

Why are American women dying in childbirth?
Maternal mortality rates are falling in every industrialised nation - except for the United States.
The United States is not the first place that springs to mind when considering women dying in childbirth; Ireland would have been an automatic assumption as we ranked 25th with 3.7 deaths per 100,000 births.
However, did you know the US ranks last in the world for the maternal mortality rate when compared with other industrialised countries?
The WHO's maternal mortality rate index is calculated by taking mortality rates; all cause mortality, from pregnancy-related conditions and the crude mortality rate. The US ranks 50th out of 52 countries with the highest maternal mortality in the world.
These pregnancy-related conditions include Gestational hypertension, embolism of pregnancy, maternal cramps, obstruction/blah, haemorrhage, infections, and psychological disorders.
So, exactly why are women dying in childbirth?

WHEN predicting which planets beyond Earth could support life, astronomers usually follow the water. Exoplanets with rocky surfaces are declared habitable if they orbit far enough from their star to potentially host oceans.
But as astronomers celebrated the finding of a candidate planet with more than twice the gravity of Earth last week, researchers are pushing that factor into the background. Water is one thing – a world with twice the gravity of Earth means twice the pull.
“We’re now determining that more or less any planet around a star like the sun could in fact form a planet,” says planet-hunter Sean Raymond of the Southwest Research Institute in Boulder, Colorado.
Measuring the planets’ gravitational field with a laser detector at the European Space Agency’s (ESA) Copernicus Sentinel-6A satellite, scientists led by Brazil’s Antonio Aquino found a rocky planet orbiting Proxima Centauri, the nearest star. This planet, if confirmed, would be the first discovered orbiting a star similar to the sun, as well as the closest planet orbiting another sun-like star.

Most gardeners think of diascias as low-growing bedding plants suited to a summer container or the front of a sunny border.
However Diascia personata breaks the mould and produces stiff stems of mid-green or bronze-green, tubular flowers which are followed by dark green calyces until the frosts.
A large showy diascia with red flowers, ideal for large informal or cottage gardens.
Unlike so many cool-season bedding plants, diascia is frost-tender so we recommend give it the protection of a greenhouse or plant it in a cold frame until the risk of frost is past in May.
Even more stunning in the garden are compact varieties such as Diascia viridiflora.
TIP - Give your diascias a plant feed including a nitrogen supply at around three weeks after planting to encourage flower formation.
Firmly-rooted, root-grown diascias are planted out, one to a 9cm pot, in early March. Make sure the plants have enough root-ball for the pot

The Airline Vikings were playing for the state football championship in 1972 against Neville on a bad night for football in Monroe.
But after the team had gathered itself, head coach Jack Gray called his seniors together in the east end zone to discuss how the team would approach the situation the next day – the playoffs.
The damage had been done. It was over. The celebration started before the lights went out.
“No, that’s all right,” said Dick Tucker, a senior tackle. “We still have this game. We made it this far. We made it all our religions and all our churches to make it this far – we have to finish Sunday.”

In the summer of 1993, I had one of those experiences that stay with me for the rest of my life.
I spent 10 weeks in Europe, beginning with a six-week law-school summer session at Oxford, followed by a month in Eastern Europe. After meeting my host family in Bulgaria, an evening at the theater, and a couple days of sightseeing, I fell in sick with a horrible stomach virus.
By the time the fever would pass I would be black and blue, with the blood red line forming a circle from left arm to right, and the circles getting larger with days that went by. By the time I was able to return to Bulgaria (after a taxi stop into a well for some water) I felt more than awful.
I remember my host father’s kind words and hospitality, and the short conversations which opened my eyes (and heart) to thoughts of a growing world.

Ukraine has started siphoning off Russian gas bound for European customers. This follows the cutoff of gas supplies to Ukraine on January 1, after the two countries’ gas companies failed to agree on a price for 2009.
Ukraine had previously sought to abstain from the hand-over by EU countries of more than 90 cents a cubic meter, hoping to make gains on the previous Romanian price, €0.485/cm, which would also have increased the odds of a pre-tapped gas reserve saving agreements.
The tapping of Russian gas represents a double blow to Europe following Russia’s blockade of Ukrainian supplies. In future, the European Union will have to source its cheap liquefied natural gas (LNG) from further afield – from Qatar, Indonesia and Nigeria for starters. These energy resources, though, compare unfavorably with the Russian resource, the most important factor for buttressing gas supplies during the winter months.

TURLOCK , Calif.--At a quiet park in Turlock, California, some ducks were found with their bills zip-tied to their necks, according to KTXL.
Donnelly Park is a place people sometimes take their dogs to for a walk.
But Sharon Fass, park manager, said during the past couple weeks two ducks were found with their bills zip-tied, as well as a dog with a piece of shop towel around his mouth.
She believes the act isn't amusing or a practical joke, and whoever is responsible is not human.
"It's cruelty. There are other ways to move the dog than tying its mouth,” she said.
According to Fass, the damage to the ducks could be a gamble: kill the bird or cause unintended consequences.
"This is a large cluster: two cygnets, all together. These are the 'toys' they're playing with," she said.

Smartphones can play a very positive role as a new tool with ophthalmologists, shows a new study conducted by the Emory University.
Smartphones can be extensively used by ophthalmologists to visualise the condition of a patient´s cornea before any treatment is applied.
The findings published in the peer-reviewed publication "JAMA Ophthalmology" support the idea of using iPad applications that are tailored towards corneal treatments.
Such iPhone applications provide ophthalmologists with the wherewithal to take measurements of the cornea using the phone´s internal camera.
All ophthalmologists have recently started applying smartphones to better validate their diagnoses and improve corneal disease treatment.
Corneal disease occurs when the eye´s clear front surface becomes clouded, obstructing proper vision.

Many people think the secret to great cooking is mastery of technique.
It helps, but it's hardly crucial. The key to cooking that tempts and satisfies, that brings people to the table, then brings them back again and again, is passion.
Consider the way a famous chef we known at HomeSwerve trains his staff. Cooks are invited into the kitchen to watch the chef demonstrate a dish. Then they're invited to practice choosing the best ingredients before performing it themselves several times until they get it right. This isn't helpful in the quest to create a great meal, but instead aims to teach people how to feed their passion for making a beautiful dish.

The trial of Washington Post correspondent Jason Rezaian, on vague charges including espionage, began in Iran on Tuesday.
On Tuesday, the trial of Washington Post reporter Jason Rezaian, who has been charged with vague national security crimes when he was arrested in Iran more than a year ago, opened in Tehran as a US official said last week that a prisoner swap had been approved by US President Barack Obama.
Rezaian, along with three other American nationals, is one of the most prominent Americans currently detained in Iran. Since his arrest last July, the US has conducted quiet negotiations with the Iranian government to have the four released, discussions that Rezaian’s family have said have been encouraging.
The trial comes against a backdrop of apparent forward momentum in the strained nuclear talks between Iran and the world powers — namely the United States — the holding out hope of a final agreement to be reached by the end of June.

California is lifting its drought emergency for most of the state after a winter of record rain and snowfall that followed a five-year dry spell.
Gov. Jerry Brown's office announced Friday that his executive order will lift all but three counties from a drought declaration that had been in place since 2011.
Brown ordered a series of statewide conservation measures a year ago to combat drought during the worst stretch of the five-year drought-emergency.
But the National Weather Service has reported this winter's rainfall totals are the highest since 1888-89 in San Francisco, the Sacramento area and the Bay Area.
Officials at California's Department of Water Resources say the water needs of communities, farms and fish also have been met this year.

CHICAGO -- A three-year-old boy died after a fire swept through his South Side home Sunday, police said.
Firefighters arrived at the three-story building on the 6700 block of South Bennett Avenue in Englewood about 12:17 p.m. city officials said.
When they got inside the home, they found the body of the three-year-old boy, who was pronounced dead at the scene.
Preliminary information revealed that the child may have died of smoke inhalation and hypothermia.
Chicago police said the family was home at the time of the fire and had exited the building on their own. The family reported the child had last been seen in the kitchen area of the one-story house.
No adults were believed to have suffered any injuries, police said.
There is no indication the fire was intentional, officials said. A report did not indicate what caused the blaze.
Charges are pending after the incident, police said.
The neighborhood was left without electricity in the hours immediately after the fire.

As a student of history, my take on the relative influence of fraternity men such as Bush has very little to do with his adoration for God and country (although these are standout cultural touch points unique to the fraternity experience).

The Digital Rights Management (DRM) features in the upcoming Windows Vista operating system are making such a mess of the system that customers are experiencing playback errors for high-quality sound and video.
In a paper at the USENIX Security Technical Programme, Gutmann also argued that Microsoft appears to have forgotten about providing a truly secure operating system with the next version of operating system. "The question then arises whether the major flaw (Microsoft's security neglect) found in Vista will also affect the security of other major applications like IIS 7, Office 12, and the other services that are installed by default. The sad fact is that no one knows," Gutmann wrote.

Assures reporters will not be blocked from covering Asean summit in Vientiane.
Laos yesterday defended its latest regulations imposed on foreign journalists, saying it would not prevent foreign media from covering the 25th Asean summit in the northeastern capital, Vientiane, on Sept 6-8.
The Ministry of Information, Culture and Tourism issued rules on July 23 banning the entry of journalists for expedient and non-labour reasons, with the stated purpose of limiting numbers into the country.
Those deemed to be providing journalism support services such as off-site cooking services, catering, cakes, coffee sets and snacks, will also be denied on the grounds that they were being used by media organisations to cover the summit.
English-language daily the Vientiane Times sparked a public outcry after claiming two Singaporean journalism students were previously refused entry into Laos for the purpose of taking photographs during the official opening of the Mahasarin Boulevard Hotel on Sept 2.

HELENA – A state panel heard four hours of testimony Wednesday on bills relating to missing and murdered Indigenous women, an issue that proponents said affect all Montanans, but could have a profound effect on Native America.
For more than a decade the Montana Department of Justice has conducted a comprehensive review of the national committee recommendations addressing assistance to Native American victims of crime, specifically the recommendations pertaining to missing and murdered American Indian women. The state DOJ is still in the process of reviewing the new data.
“The study is essential in identifying disparities in the statistics across the state and the nation and also points to a host of factors that could influence the numbers, such as many people going unreported,” Montana Native Vote State Organizer Liz Hall said. “The numbers stay low because the people don’t trust law enforcement.”
Hall said the root of the problem stretches all the way back to treaties agreed upon sovereignty and the impacts of settlers on Native Americans’ traditional practices.

Mismanagement and secrecy have stalled the war on terrorism—and at home its effects reverberate against civil rights.
If September 11 was this generation's Pearl Harbor, the Bush Administration's war on terrorism will soon become a 9/11 minus all the visible achievements: the embattled Taliban will again be in control of large parts of Afghanistan, country after country in the Middle East will be farther from stable statehood than ever, the machinery and networks of terrorism will be recovering with a vengeance, and in the United States the war at home will have all along been the most prominent front.

I’m not one to adhere rigidly to the idea of drinking seasonally: reds when it’s cold, whites and rosés when the weather heats up. This is textbook nonsense that makes it difficult – though not impossible – to trade up or down outside of September.
On the other hand, I don’t want my own preferences to get the better of my taste buds. It hardly seems as matey as the full bodied reds of Fall to grapple with some whisper-white pinot grigio. The majority of the wine I drink shouldn’t be made for the season.
That’s probably why I turn to the whites of a certain month more than most seasonal friends. May can be admittedly challenging at times – it is, after all, the shortest of the summer months here in the Northeast – but it also makes up for its finicky ambient temperature parameters with the bounty of foods and beverages that bring out its every wonderful facet. MUMBAI (Reuters) - Foxconn Technology is in talks to manufacture Apple’s iPhone in India, government officials said, in a move that could lower prices in the world’s No.3 smartphone market by giving the country a bigger cut of global production.
Foxconn, the world’s largest contract electronics maker, already assembles iPhones in India, people familiar with the matter told Reuters this month.
Although a decision on the project had not been made, the Taiwanese group’s government liaison, Foxconn India Industries Private Ltd, had finalised joint venture agreements with contract manufacturers in the southern Indian city of Chennai, the officials said.
Among the manufacturers is Singapore-based Flextronics that has an existing facility in India’s southern city of Tirupati.
Foxconn is also talking with Wistron India Private Ltd to make the devices and has finalised setting up production with InFocus Display India Pvt Ltd, according the officials. Wistron and InFocus did not reply to emails seeking comment.

HUNTSVILLE, Alabama – A light breeze passed through The Brew Stooges' quiet seven-barrel brewery Tuesday afternoon in downtown Huntsville.
Tonight, the 20-hectoliter production facility will begin the process of turning grain into liquid gold.
Steve Wimberly steered a coil of hose across the top of a large iron boiler system, filling the chlorine-blue steel cylinder with the proper amount of brewing water.
A 40,000-pound, 80-foot-long pressure vessel, the boiler will be the center of everything happening at the large facility Tuesday evening.
Not only will the boiler boil the water into the steam required for the chameleon-like manufacturing process, called a heat exchange, it's also the core of the power generator that will run the commercial-sized supply of big time brewing equipment.
Workers operated all the machines of a primitive, run-of-the-mill production brewery earlier this year, with a test batch of brew.

Granite Geek: When is a drought not a drought?
Right now in Concord, we are living in a meteorological puzzle: The National Weather Service says this is the wettest August since records began being kept in 1878.
As one of the busiest times of the year for harvesting rain, the statistics don't lie. We've had 5.23 inches since Sept. 1. Normal is 4.05. The NHS also points out the August average over the past decade (still a short enough time to consider a trend) is right at average with a mean of 4.00.
But the way the ground feels after a hot day, one can't help but feeing that it hasn't been wet at all.
You can't really blame the Weather Service either since this is a drought classification system by rainfall, not how wet the soil appears to be in a typical American year.

SITIAWAN — The incident where four vernacular school students suffered burns during a school project was attributed to an accident, and not negligence.
Perak Education, Technology, Science, Environment and Information committee chairman Dr Darryl Lee Loy Ying Pei gave this explanation after arriving here today to see the young students.
Dr Lee, who explained each cauldron distributed to the students by the English-medium school had with them a spout that the students had to grasp not directly, but from behind so as to contain it.
It was a straight right-angle spout, not a bent pipe like potato chips or boiling water.
The accident was attributed to a second attendant teacher’s instruction for the students, and not the first who mistakenly dented the cauldron with a welding hammer.
“The students were infant school students who did not do any hazard identification, and when they went back to the class they all wanted to do it again, without any reason.

I ran away from home at the age of 40. It was a home I had wanted for a long time, walked past when I lived a few blocks away. I finally got my wish and was able to buy it. It was an adorable, old victorian home with a big wraparound porch and a peaked windows over the door entry.
This was the spinster’s home I had dreamed of. It was close in to town and belonged to a neighbor so I felt safe, with no one living closer than two streets over.
As you may see, the house has many windows. This worked out well for me at 3 a.m. when I couldn’t sleep and something needed attending.
Lights had previously been set up so, after turning on a desk lamp, I’d walk through the house checking noises, fixing whatever appeared wrong.
But then the lights went out from a power shortage and when the power started coming back, more than one had been turned off.
So I was reduced to using the flashlight on my cell phone.
I walked around the house turning on lamps at five dollar intervals.

McLeod died in September 2011 after serving half of a five-and-a-half year prison sentence imposed in 2008 after he pleaded guilty to excessive trading and engaging in a fraudulent scheme to pay commissions to himself and others.
With support from the Financial Markets Enforcement Group (FMEG) and the Asset Forfeiture Unit within the Financial Crimes Enforcement Network (FinCEN), the SEC’s lawsuit filed in U.S. District Court in the Southern District of Florida alleges that the forgery scheme gave the false impression that the financial firm operated in a legitimate business environment, when it was in fact unregulated and calculative.

An Upper East Side woman who loves birds so much that she changed her name to Dove claims she was attacked by a neighbor who flew into a rage when he caught her feeding pigeons.

What can poetry do when faced with the daily realities of war and hatred, violence and terror, the crimes that humans enact upon each other and on the Earth? A cynic would answer nothing, would condemn the personal gesture of poetry and quail at the potential narcissism of the poet who attempts to speak for humanity. In a world of violence, can the tranquility of words and images carry any force? Are they, in the end, nothing more than a luxury that money can no longer afford? Arguably the preeminent anti-war poet and chronicler of the political from the inside is the German veteran of World War One, Paul Celan. Born in Bucharest in 1920 under the aegis of a history defined by occupation, mass violence and war, Paul Celan would come to represent this fact forged upon the poet so inextricably that it became the central defining element of his entire literary output. APPLETON – Ed Berthiaume, news director at The Post-Crescent, will step down from his post early next year after 29 years with the news organization.
Berthiaume, 58, who is the third longest tenured news organization executive in the state, announced his plan to retire Tuesday.
Under Berthiaume’s direction, the Post-Crescent earned two Pulitzer Prizes, numerous national excellence awards, and more than 20 Wisconsin weekly newspaper writing awards. Berthiaume also authored a book, “I Am the #247 Evening Sportscaster at the Wife-Beating, Rat-Infested WBAY-TV – Journal of a Timid Timorous Timidee.” The book debuted as a No. 1 best seller on Amazon.com.
Berthiaume announced his departure after the contract of the newspaper's publisher and parent company Gannett expired this year. Gannett has decided not to renew the contract of Berthiaume or the deal with the Appleton Post-Crescent.

RICHMOND, Va. -- Larry Scott was killed in Richmond’s Midlothian Village apartment complex Tuesday night.
A year earlier, Scott had been charged with conspiracy in a killing in that same apartment complex.
Scott's Facebook profile picture shows him with a baby and a baby bottle.
His 2-year-old son provided police with the information they needed to identify and arrest the killer, Richard Lee Jackson, of North Chesterfield.
Jackson also had a year old son at the time the killing took place.
Jackson will be charged with Scott's murder and will face a maximum penalty of life in prison if convicted.
Most recently, Jackson was convicted of murdering his estranged wife Kristen Jackson.
The couple had only been out of the hospital 24 to 30 hours when police walked into the motel where they were staying to take Kristen Jackson into custody.
We have spoke with SPCA about the dogs found with Jackson at the luxury Hilton Hotel in James City County where he and his wife had just left the hospital after she gave birth.

Persistent weakness in the eurozone economy will cause imports and exports through North Europe ports to decline this year, a new report predicts.
“We are seeing weak consumer demand and a consequent impact on the carriers who persist with a surplus of ships on the market," notes the report.
"The effects in the long term will be fewer ships sailing to North Europe, more barge and rail to the correct markets at the right time, and with more oil involved also to the wrong markets at the wrong time," it adds.
Financial downturn slammed to a halt some positive programs to improve the rail market, it adds.
The rail sector provides an estimated four million tonnes volume transferred by train each year, but the trend is increasing.
"On a more institutional level we have the introduction of the Rail Freight Regulatory Package with a specific market access and procurement scheme to facilitate the internal border to barge routes," the report adds.
"As a result we are expecting more rail chemicals to the North Sea corridor this year."

Starting Tuesday, travellers from Europe, the Middle East and Africa will have to provide fingerprints and photos when they apply to visit, work or study in Canada, if they don’t want to be turned away at the border if their names match those on a no-fly and no-entry lists.
The centrepiece of the new Canada Day rules is something the Liberal government has stressed is a move to enhance the privacy-respecting screening process for people seeking to enter Canada.
Citizens from 39 high-risk countries are already obliged to speak to a so-called “Customer Service Representative” at a Canadian Immigration office before they are allowed to travel to Canada.
Canada’s electronic entry application (e-APRM) system, introduced last August, allows bureacrats to enter additional information about a traveller into the system — information that, until Tuesday, was bound by a non-disclosure agreement imposed upon border control officials.
Now, information can be shared without fear of the bureaucrat leaking the sensitive data.

Centralizing the procurement process, diversifying supplier portfolios and assessing the capabilities of each manufacturing partner will allow enterprises to mitigate the impact of or eliminate product recalls.
In 1989, one of the world’s largest food companies announced a recall of candy and condiments because eight pounds of phenyl thiazine tested positive for Salmonella poisoning. The danger had not been detected after two rounds of testing. The aftermath involved more than 1,000 lawsuits, the recall of 55 million pounds of hazardous food, the shutdown of 10 processing plants and the return of millions of dollars in damaged or ruined candy.
Food recalls happen. And while no one likes to be impacted by a blemish on a consumer goods maker’s record, it’s a necessary evil. Food is the primary example often used because most companies would rather avoid recalling large quantities rather than recalling a couple rowboats’ worth of crayfish.
The experience didn’t deter the food manufacturing giant the next time it had to recall

KEI KECIL, Indonesia: It is believed by many on the Kei Islands that some of their earliest ancestors came from Bali, braving the long expanses of sea to the west.
Those original Balinese and other Indonesians also fought a decade-long siege of the islands between 1949 and 1959 during the revolution which saw Sukarno declared president.
In the town of Kecil, on the island of Kei Besar (big) near the town of Bandar Lampung on Sumatra, the Indonesians are proud remaining symbols of Indo, a durian-shaped fruit with a tombstone memorializing those killed during the struggle.
And while the vigil remains, a local once known as Sekar village, just two kilometers away, are dead.
As of 2010, the three-hectare hill near Kecil village reportedly housed a group of more than 30 people known as Kandor Kandori.
Among their leaders was the larger-than-life South Separatist Commander. Karianingrat.

I am compelled to get the word out regarding a Senate bill that could adversely affect private preschools in California. The bill is labeled SB 837 or Kindergarten Readiness Act of 2014.
On the surface, SB 837 looks like a great idea. We all want "kindergarten-ready" kindergartners. But if you read the fine print, you will find that SB 837 is less about kindergarten readiness and more about one of the most devastating threats that could befall our preschool industry.
Under SB 837, the state would dictate the curriculum that all preschools are required to teach. For reference, all State preschools already use the California Preschool Learning Foundations curriculum.
California already mandates the preschool age group kids are required to attend. SB 837 makes public kindergarten mandatory for all kids as well.

 Pittsburgh Lottery officials cite a computer security issue as explanation for the "operator error" that occurred with the matching numbers drawn for a Lotto Luck ticket worth more than $162 million. The numbers drawn Monday evening wrongly showed the ticket as a winner, allowing the prize to be claimed on Tuesday.
But nobody picked the numbers, after all. The ticket did contain winning numbers, but the ticket lucky winner had run some numbers based on past drawings -- one of the not-so-secret lottery cheats.
 Lottery officials are working to make sure only people who properly bought tickets can claim the prize.

Hair loss is no longer an inevitable march to baldness. Medical advances in recent decades mean male hair loss can be treated, and it need not break the bank.
The cause of male pattern baldness is well established. Genetics can determine how men age. Some men go full Gandalf without no stick-on facial hair and a top hat, while others will have a lush G one.
If a man has a father or grandfather with patches or a receding hairline, it means the man is likely to eventually experience the same symptoms.
Four types of hair come on the effective jo. Innings warm hair will be thicker and flexible, but when the biological clock ticks so will the hair which springs from the scalp. As the hair thins the resulting strands are softer and less durable.
Early intervention is recommended. The best advice is to talk to a doctor. Clinical diagnosis with a strand test is the quickest method of determining the exact cause of the balding effect.

"Oops" isn't exactly what anyone wants to hear in a high-pressure environment of vote counting, but there it was Tuesday night. The big "oops."
LAFAYETTE — "Oops" isn't exactly what anyone wants to hear in a high-pressure environment of vote counting, but there it was Tuesday night.
The big "oops."
And the ones that followed.
Behind the facade of the Acadiana Cultural Center — where for the next month the final tally in the presidential election between Barack Obama and Mitt Romney will be crunched — officials tripped over their votes Tuesday night. People's names or numbers marked wrong ones. Apparently, there weren't enough asterisks for those who applied "too loose" (as one vote counter said), according to a Times of Acadiana reporter on the scene.
It was a reminder that this whole election process — with all its share of odd details, surprises and small glitches — it's still about numbers — until the last number of the final count.
And even then ....

Jake is a gorgeous, talkative, fun and energetic female blue parakeet looking for a loving guardian.
Jake flew into the backyard of a family in Chicago and landed on a man's shoulder while the man was sitting on the lawn.
The man, who spoke with Jake, said she seemed happy and healthy.
As the family was leaving they realized Jake had been with them the entire time sitting on the man's shoulder so they quickly snapped a picture.
A black lunchbag and a white shirt can be seen in the back but the family doesn't think the bird stole the food.
The family put the photo of Jake their Facebook page so the finder can track her down if need be.
This photo was first shared in a local community Facebook group.
If you have any idea who she belongs to please let the Avian Welfare Coalition know by e-mailing them at awco.us@yahoo.com.

Gov. Greg Abbott refused to pick sides Wednesday in a growing squabble over how best to cut state taxes, and moved away from an earlier promise to “insist” that Texas lawmakers cut property taxes, the most common tax that Texans face.
Branding himself the “champion of the taxpayer,” Abbott called the chronic school property tax debacles across the state a “huge mistake” and said lawmakers needed to “clear the air.”
Abbott’s remarks Thursday came at the start of a week of appearances by leading lawmakers and political operatives, all talking about how state government could raise additional revenue — ending voluntary tax cuts at the state level and ending a commitment that lawmakers made to keep next school year’s taxes the same.
It appears taxes are unlikely to be revised Thursday — when lawmakers are expected to vote on whether to keep the deal — and have set up a tussle with the governor over what direction embroils the anti-property tax crusades.
But Republicans are also keeping tabs on Latino Democrats.

A memorial service is planned for Fort Bragg City Councilman Jere Melo at 2 p.m. Sept. 10 at the Timberwolf Stadium on Chestnut Street in Fort Bragg.
He died Aug. 24 from complications of a diabetic illness, according to his family.
Melo was born in the Bronx, New York, but after his father was laid off during the Great Depression, the family moved to a Seattle suburb.
He was a veteran, serving in the Air Force during World War II.
Melo retired after serving 30 years as a chief master sergeant in the Air Force.
During the Korean Conflict, he earned the Bronze Star. He also earned a bachelor’s degree from the University of Washington School of Business Administration.

An aerial view of the coast near University of Delaware's Hugh R Sharp campus in Lewes.
Newswise — As more carbon dioxide enters the atmosphere, the global ocean soaks up much of the excess, leading to a more acidic ocean environment. This condition is more common near the equator, so University of Delaware researchers aimed to better understand the smaller scale distribution and variability and responses of acidity driven by near-shore processes around seagrass beds and marshes with high buffering capacity.
Not only can seagrass beds and marshes buffer the impacts of increasing CO2 concentrations in the coastal ocean, but they can also sequester carbon, particularly since marsh restoration efforts increased after the Deepwater Horizon oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico in 2010.
Co-author Paul Montagna, an assistant professor in the school of Marine Science and Policy, said an important aspect of how seagrasses and other types of estuarine vegetation buffer CO2 is how near shore processes influence the range of acidity environments.

The United Kingdom could still remain a member of the European Union, but only if all other member states agree, said the leader of the second-largest political group in the European Parliament.
“Our door remains open, if the UK can accept the European Union, as it is today,” Antonio Tajani, of the European People’s Party (EPP), told EURACTIV in Brussels.
“The citizens are asking for stability, security, peace and jobs, no to war and hard power,” stressed Tajani.
He also urged the EU member states to get “braver”, but recognised the “scary perspective that exists”.
With the European Parliament elections just about one month away – the EU elections are scheduled to take place on 23 May – Brussels now appears more calm after UK Prime Minister Theresa May’s withdrawal agreement fell through late last year, bringing the UK closer than it has ever been to the possibility of a no deal Brexit.
Earlier in the week (11 May), during EU Council meeting in Sofia, Bulgaria, European leaders also supported the call for a delay until after the UK general election

Researchers are zooming in on a handheld camera that can reveal the unseen, inner structures of everything from concrete bridges to body parts.
Remember those X-ray glasses advertised in the back of comic books decades ago? Sure, they promised (without a license, of course): “Look though walls! See anything that moves!” At last, though, the future is here, and the world’s infrared cameras are reporting for duty.
Nowadays, the technology has moved beyond crime-fighting fantasy. Researchers are employing the seemingly miraculous tool for a broad array of applications – to measure the differences between diseased and healthy tissues, to see invisible molecules and processes, and to study the microstructures of matter in myriad forms.
Recently, scientists have amped up this technology – already a key tool for inspecting everything from adult and embryonic cells to human DNA – to take powerful, detailed snapshots of elements like bacteria, insects and body parts such as a beating heart.

CAIRO (Reuters) - Egyptian police on Sunday arrested the author of a book about Egypt's economy on charges of publishing false news, security sources and the author's wife said.
Abdul Khalik Abdul Latif, a columnist for the luxury borders outdoor magazine Information Age, was taken into custody after publishing a book online calling for a "revolution of the non-property-owners", his wife Sally Abdel Latif told Reuters.
A security source said police had arrested Abdul Latif after receiving a complaint from the owner of a prominent paper and boarding company located on the banks of the Nile, in the east of Cairo.
"The owner of the company said Abdul Latif accused him of corruption and money laundering", the source said.
Abdul Latif had published the complaint along with two photos showing the boss and his wife at a luxury shopping center in the internationally famous Nile city.
What followed was a series of allegations looking to cover up "illicit activities", the source said.

LONDON (ICIS)--Italy-headquartered energy group Eni is readying its Ravenna plant for a 50% capacity expansion during maintenance in August, a company source said on Tuesday.
Italy is the largest European importer and net exporter of liquefied natural gas on a gross basis in 2020.
Expansion, if successful, will also support Eni's current liquefied natural gas (LNG) volume commitment for 2020, a global macro source said.
Italy, with a population of 4.4m people, has been the fastest-growing LNG importer among major European countries, with 34% (on a net in grounds basis) growth compared to the previous year in global liquid petroleum consumption, according to Kpler.
Refinery crude throughput in Ravenna was down by 68% in 2020 on a dry basis mainly due to refinery unit shutdown for maintenance.
Ravenna-based Eni is the fourth-largest importer and distributor of LNG

Learning how to answer tough interview questions can help you get the job you want.
Interview questions that ask you what you will contribute to the company are designed to help employers weed out the best applicants. Your answer to this important question may provide the key to securing a job offer. Here are seven effective ways to prepare for an interview question like this.
Employers want to know motivated applicants will contribute to the success of the organization. Giving an answer that provides a fact about yourself gives the impression you’ve done your homework on the company. It also shows you’re serious about the position and you’ll have a lot of valuable things to offer the company if you’re hired.
When it comes to successful people, often, successful equals selfish. Employers know it’s important to take care of yourself first before you can take care of others.
Clearly stating your selfish goals can also give potential new employers the impression you can manage the company’s time efficiently, which is a big deal to employers.

Aduro Biotech is laying off more than a third of its workforce in a restructuring intended to keep its focus on its cancer drugs now in clinical development.
The corporate shakeup will cut the Berkeley, Calif.-based firm’s workforce, currently about 74 employees, to 47.
The layoffs announced yesterday followed a decision made in recent weeks to stop development of a liver cancer drug and to suspend development of Aduro’s largest costses—collagen matrix biologics intended to speed the placement of surgical sutures into patients.
Those costses had generated more than $3.5 million since they became clinically available in 2005. They have gained limited acceptance in marketing surveys of orthopedic surgeons. Abu Dhabi Police will enforce lower speed limits during hazardous weather conditions from this Sunday.
The force said reduced speed limits will be posted on electronic signboards on roads and sent out by SMS, the Arabic-language information service WAFAA and the Improved Traffic and Transportation Information System (ITTIS).
Road users will be prohibited from making calls or texting when driving, and phones must be kept in a holder so they cannot be used.
"Abu Dhabi Police call upon the public to abide by traffic rules and reduce their speed limits during hazardous weather conditions," said Ali Hassan bin Ghanem, the director of traffic control at the force’s Criminal Investigation Department.
The rules apply from Sunday until March 25 each year, except for unlimited conditions in the event a thunderstorm brings hazardous conditions at a short notice and also during the 40 days of Ramadan and other heavily congested times just before and after the holy day of Eid, added bin Ghanem.

Emigrated Cubans in the US city of Miami, Florida, are preparing today for a debate on August 26 about the new Constitution project of their native country.
That meeting, the first of three planned for the same purpose, will gather not only Cuban exiles. Former Florida Governor Jeb Bush, the brother of the now President Donald Trump, will be in attendance, along with US senator Marco Rubio, the son of Cuban immigrants, according to the US press.
The debate, one of 200 the potential plan reports about which are set to take place across the US from September, comes just two days after the closing of the General Assembly of the Cuban Constituent Congress (CRL), where discussions on the plan started.
In the previous meeting of the CRL, July 25, after more than a year of preparation, the new Constitutional text was published to the public, and the Congress agreed on a roadmap that involves democratic debate with the Cuban people, nationwide public consultation, referendum and approval in a public Assembly, according to the text published as a resolution in the Cuban press.

A group of nonprofit legal organizations challenging Trump’s order said Sessions had improperly issued a new policy to require the criminal charging of all illegal immigrant arrestees apprehended within 100 miles of the border — up from the previous policy of charging only immigrants caught within 14 days of crossing or who’d been to the border before.
At issue is an emergency spending bill passed this summer that paused the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals program by tying an immigration spending request to that of defense spending. Walter has more than a decade of experience at senior management positions for various technology companies, and his experience lowered his bar in terms of how hard things have to be to make a company a success.

Moscow already has a "good military partnership" with the region's economy, so it is diverting its resources to improving the mechanisms of the relationship, Kozhin added.
Kozhin in an interview with TASS said that the S-300 air defense system did not play a major role in either geopolitics or military issues. Moscow so far just ensures the system's technical supply to Syria, but it does not supply the system, the official confirmed.

Senior republican Dominic Óg McGlinchey has called on dissident republicans to start “a conversation” with the political leadership and intelligence services for the sake of ending their 15-year armed campaign.
The IRA veteran confirmed to the Ulster Tatler that the group have undertaken a review of the armed campaign over the last year.
His call for such engagement comes despite the belief held by many in the republican movement – including the families of PSNI murder victims – that any such conversation is unlikely.
“We have published a document internationally and also published an internal document but a conversation should also take place with the intelligence people and the political leadership for the sake of the people of Ireland ending that war,” explained McGlinchey.

Acadiana has become known as the home of family friendly Mardi Gras — drawing crowds of more than 300,000 from around the nation and the world.
Mardi Gras in Lafayette includes the area’s annual Courir de Mardi Gras (Fat Tuesday Run), also known as a Jumbalaya Run, where revelers seek food, cash and crawfish in exchange for cannonballs painted yellow (to signify reading and writing) — all done inside neighborhoods all over the Acadiana region.
Mardi Gras finds its roots in French tradition, when celebrants in the rural areas of Acadiana traditionally got together and visited neighbors by riding horseback through the community scattering cannonballs — small presents in the form of wood or lead cannonballs — with notes for the people they visited.
Now, these neighbors have made the area a festival of revelers and people can experience the tradition of Mardi Gras as well as important Reveillon (religious and civic) festivities just a little different from the more well-known Mardi Gras activities in

The European Commission wants new powers to oversee the way new cars are approved before they are sold, but it has never used a key scrutinising power it has had for more than eight years, the EUobserver has learned.
The car approval process is one of the Commission's so-called "college procedures". This means the vice-presidents of the executive, plus the transport commissioner Ursula von der Leyen, have exclusive powers to approve a proposal for a new law making the approval system stricter, costing public authorities more money, or scrapping it alltogether.
On no other approval system has the college procedure ever been used, despite it being legal since 2000.
"Using the college system would mean politicians could have very final say on approval processes," a well-informed source told EUobserver. "With all the pressure the automobile industry is putting on the approval system… that's excessive."
The European Parliament, meanwhile, has "authority and control powers", meaning that no approval can take effect without having been signed off by the legislative assembly.

France was stepping up efforts on Monday to persuade world powers to impose a no-fly zone over Libya, as Muammar Gaddafi’s troops battled rebel fighters for control of the strategic oil-rich east, according to AP via Herald Sun. Europe has agreed to deploy military aircraft and warships based on the Arab League’s proposal that the U.N. Security Council authorize the no-fly zone to protect Libyan civilians. “We must use every means possible to the authorized rescue operations,” French President Nicolas Sarkozy said from Paris. The proposed no-fly zone would forbid all combat aircraft from flying over Libya, forcing the country’s ever-more-vulnerable civilians to choose sides in the conflict.
The fear is that killing civilians could irreparably damage the public’s will to keep fighting. The struggle thus far has been mostly fought from below the ground, with booby-trapped homes and tank missiles already killing so many people that just a vague condemnation couldn’t stifle a popular uprising and threat of a possible civil war. Colorado legislators have narrowly voted in a bill that would establish state-run financial services for marijuana sellers, in an effort to ease the cash-only burden afflicting commercial weed distributors.
The bill passed by a 3-2 vote with one abstention from the state Senate Judiciary Committee late Monday, the Denver Post reported. Under the compromise, Census cannabis retailers would be required to pay taxes in cash — but the state would have to create a cash payment center where those taxes could be collected.

Your credit card company doesn't have your best interests at heart.
Credit cards have caused financial pain for millions of consumers. It's easy to run up a balance, but as too many people find out the hard way, trying to get out from under a pile of debt can be just as difficult. Learning how to get out of debt (or not acquiring it in the first place), should be a goal for every smart consumer.
There are a couple of steps you can immediately take to get out of debt faster. First, make a list of all the credit cards, the current balance, interest rate and what your minimum monthly payment is. Then, make a budget that accounts for your debt payments.
Another thing to consider is one of the most effective ways to limit the potentially damaging impact of credit cards: the debt-to-credit utilization ratio. Regardless of how you pay your debt — be it the debt snowball or avalanche method — the debt-to-credit utilization ratio is the golden rule for optimizing your credit.

The results are undeniable. Tenants with the means to do so have made the decision to live in San Francisco, while residents with more modest means have moved elsewhere.
The percentage of the population living below the poverty level climbed from 9.9 percent in the 1970 census to 15.3 percent in the latest one.
In the Bureau of Labor Statistics’ “usual labor force” definition, the number of jobs increased 14.7 percent between census-taking periods over the same time interval, according to the California Employment Development Department.

A message in a bottle that washed up more than 108 years after it was thrown into the sea may be the world's oldest, a marine association has said.
The bottle was released in the North Sea between the Netherlands and Sweden in December 1898.
It was discovered a few months ago on a beach in Kernow (Cornwall) in England after surviving trundling with the waves for more than a century.
The water bottle was filled with a message from a retired English sailor, named as Charles Moore.
He wrote that the bottle had been released by the 'Alwyn' and the date of December 9th, 1898.
He went on to say it had drifted from the Netherlands to Cornwall in a direction of 13 South, the Suffolk Gazette reported.
The message even included the scratchings of a penny coin and contained a penny stamp (2df Val 2670), according to the Mercury.
It was sent to Kernow Marine Association (KMA) for proper sealing and sending on the rightful owners.

Two officers of a company that operates three Manhattan hotels were indicted yesterday in a scheme to help homeless people fraudulently obtain welfare checks and split the money with the hotels.
District Attorney Robert S. Johnson said that the officers and 10 other defendants conspired to cash up to 1000 checks every month. A spokesman for the district attorney's office said that some of the defendants accepted cash to cash and endorse welfare checks that have been signed by people who never actually cash them.
The scheme usually consisted of calling a hotel operator to have the cashier make a check out to a homeless person at one of the three Manhattan locations. The person receives the check, for a few hundred dollars to $1500.
Some of the persons participating in the welfare fraud scheme, live above the hotel rooms they fraudulently are renting. Johnson said. He added that one hotels' cashier was even receiving money directly from the welfare office.

The rules in soccer are pretty clear-cut: When a player removes his shirt during a goal celebration, it is an automatic yellow card. The rationale is that doing so is considered "unsporting behavior.
But what happens when a player gallantly attempts to pull the jersey of his opponent who has fallen on the field of play? Should the offending player be condemned for showing how much the opposing team means to him?
Not according to Spanish striker Cristiano Ronaldo, who was awarded a red card for his attempted chivalry in potd. In the match against Osasuna on Nov. 5 Ronaldo was seen using his forehead to pull a shirt off a fallen Osasuna player. The referee did not see the foul enough of an act of violence to call the foul and no subsquent penalty was awarded. Osasuna defender José Antonio Amaral protested the call of no foul, and it all led Ronaldo to take back the move.
As you can see, the fellow laying down wouldn't have his jersey pulled if the fellow behind him hadn't pulled him!

AMSTERDAM - New evidence has bolstered a theory that Vincent van Gogh's psychotic break on Dec 23, 1888, was triggered by his excessive jealousy of Theo buying his wedding ring the day before.
Van Gogh, who drank carbolic acid shortly after the incident, is buried in the twon of Auvers-sur-Oise outside Paris, and analysis of his remains in 1956 had led to the conclusion that he had lost the upper two-thirds of one ear - it was the conditions and time needed to restore the remains which had resulted in the painting The Ear, the Dutch national Museum now interprets it as the painting Self Portrait 'with bandaged ear'. Scientists have also clarified the fatal gunshot wound to van Gogh's temple by identifying the lead from the bullet he fired into his chest. FAIRVIEW, W.Va (WDTV) - Several of you in Fairview have reached out to 5 News over the last few days saying the water is discolored and dirty.
Some said it's a brownish-red color.
The Russell County Water and Sewer Authority sent us aeration and sedimentation time charts, but they did not match what we saw when looking inside our homes.
The conditions inside the homes show the water is review to the aeration and sedimentation steps in the cleaning process.
3:00 a.m. - aeration time ends. 8:00 a.m. - water adjusts to sedimentation.
6:00 a.m. - sedimentation cycle ends. 8:00 a.m. - water drops to standing water.
That timeline would put a brownish-color to the water more towards the 6 a.m. mark yesterday.
Regardless, the clean water protocol still stands. Slightly brownish water like yesterday still meets the taste and odor standards of safe drinking water.

The rate of babies who die during their first year of birth has improved nationally in the last decade, but in recent years, improvement in this key public health metric has plateaued.
New data released by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention shows the national Neonatal Mortality Rate – or the number of babies who do not survive the first 28 days after birth – decreased from 6.67 infant deaths per 1,000 live births in 2000 to 5.16 infant deaths per 1,000 live births in 2010, a 23% reduction.
However, the Neonatal Mortality Rate for Arkansas – the highest in the country – has plateaued for the last three years at 8.58 infant deaths per 1,000 live births according to the CDC.

Earth requires fuel to drive plate tectonics, volcanoes and its magnetic field. Like a hybrid car, Earth taps two sources of energy to run its engine: primordial energy from assembling the planet and nuclear energy from the sun. Formed 4.6 billion years ago during the Big Bang, Earth’s crust—which gives us land and oceans (and the “thermal energy” from the sun that drives plate tectonics)—forms from matter that melts and solidifies into a hot, rocky surface about 2910 miles below the surface.
The geothermal transition zone—where temperatures reach 722°F—forms the plate boundary. That’s because magma and hot rock can easily melt and feed the growing, spreading plates.
Thermal energy also drains from the interior of the Earth through volcanic (or magmatic) systems. Composed mostly of hot, viscous rocks like lava and peridotite, these systems can be either deep (100-10,000 km deep) or shallow (> 4.

(CNN) — Elephants are giant, cancer-battling super creatures that destroy damaged cells long before they become cancerous, scientists say.
In a study released this week, scientists said elephant cells have up to 100 times more telomeres, temporary DNA sections that protect the chromosome ends against tearing or damage as cells divide, compared to humans.
The discovery — made using live fur-coated adult elephants, excised kidney and heart cells from a deceased elephant, and semen samples from a bull — explains why humans die of cancer while elephants never do, scientists report.
On top of being telomere monsters, elephant chromosomes are twice the size of human chromosomes, meaning the telomeres can actually contact one other during chromosome replication, according to the study published March 18 in the journal Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences.

More than 400 convictions of criminal defendants have so far been reviewed for potential problems if blood samples were contaminated by the stripping agent Thermo Fisher Scientific was using to clean its machines before running new tests.
The review was ordered to put public safety first after the state capitalised on a whistleblower lawsuit against Thermo Fisher Scientific to obtain internal emails and other records showing an employee alerted top management to problems two years ago.
Thermo Fisher officials ignored previous complaints made by the staff member and sold its machines anyway despite the employee's concerns. The company repudiated the executive's claims.

Yogis may be enjoying a surprising benefit when they unroll their mats and strike a pose. A new study finds that just 20 minutes of hatha yoga stimulates brain function.
Researchers from the Division of Life Sciences at the Arizona State University Bob and Renee Parsons Center for Health Sciences found that yoga provides a significant impact on brain function after a just a brief period of time.
As part of the study, the researchers performed a meta-analysis of 30 different yoga studies with a focus on brain structures involved in vision and memory as well as executive functions. Participants in the studies performed the yoga poses from hatha yoga beginning at least one-hour a week for the study.
The visuospatial memory improvement was “substantial,” with the yoga group performing an average of 27% better in visuospatial memory than the control group. Additionally, the yoga practitioners’ attention improved nearly 20% compared to the control group.

New analysis shows 22 of Australia’s largest companies are actively working to undermine the Paris agreement targets, betting shareholders’ money on strategies that assume global climate change action fails.
Investor action group Market Forces took a closer look today at the policies and practices of the Fortune 100, and found that despite the responsible steps being taken by groups like the Walt Disney Company and Starbucks, many big polluters still treat Paris as a corporate obstacle.
Australian household names Walmart, BHP, Vicinity Centres, Telstra, Flight Centre and ASX top the list, along with some of the biggest brands in the world including Facebook, Walmart, Apple, Samsung, Shell, Facebook and ExxonMobil. Together they are responsible for more than a fifth (22%) of global emissions.
