Composting is the ultimate win-win-win for gardeners.
It is recycling at its most basic, turning yard and kitchen waste into rich, organic planting material. It saves money on fertilizer and chemicals at a time when they cost more and have become a rarer commodity. It also saves large amounts of energy required in the production of chemical fertilizers and reduces the amount of organic waste (which often ends up in a landfill) going to the curb, saving tons of greenhouse gases each year.
Composting isn’t a difficult task – in fact, it’s so simple that anyone can do it. All that’s required is a container large enough to hold the waste, some way to aerate the contents and a bit of time.
Most choose a small plastic bin (worth starting with these before the smell can make your neighbors cry) with either a spigot (runs to city sewer) or a cover with a hole for air. For aeration, some choose compost bins that are aerated by a rotation, others turn the compost pile by another method (

Stanley Karnow, the award-winning author and journalist who wrote a definitive book about the Vietnam War, worked on an accompanying documentary and later won a Pulitzer for a history of the Philippines, died Sunday morning. He was 88.
Karnow died of pneumonia at a hospital in Washington, D.C., said his daughter Maya.
Karnow's acclaimed work on Vietnam, "Very Long War," won a Pulitzer Prize in the International Reporting category in 1965 and the National Book Award.
He wrote that he had no time while living the slow Vietnamese life and had wondered if there was a better way of capturing the war than taking snap judgments in the moments a mobile plane made its landing.
After his history of Vietnam was published in 1968, he produced the PBS documentary "The Battle of Vietnam" with script writer David Sabaroff. Two years later he won a National Book Award for his history, "History of the Philippines."
Since leaving Vietnam in 1967, Karnow planned to stay out of journalism and continue writing only books.

A report by the Wall Street Journal suggests that Dell could be on the verge of becoming a public company once again.
The deal could be announced as soon as later today and -- if the cited sources close to Dell are correct -- the $25 billion sale would slash Dell's debt by half.
The once-revered PC and server maker became a private entity in September of 2013 when it went public with a $25 billion, leveraged buyout.
Dell faced a $34 billion takeover by proxy in March after major shareholder Carl Icahn and his affiliated parties accumulated an 8.5 percent stake.
Though the report does not indicate what price shareholders will fetch for the PC maker, Bloomberg cites a person with knowledge of the matter stating the company has been valued at more than $20 a share.
This would be the second major technology takeover announced this week following HP's planned acquisition of Samsung's printer business.

Decision trees help people identify the pros and cons of business choices.
A decision tree is a visual tool used to help business professionals weigh the pros, cons and various approaches to major tasks or decisions. A decision tree can help professionals identify the potential impact of the options they consider with a task. The diagram shows the consequences of a decision – the probability of the decisions' outcomes, while a summary at the base of the tree shows the possible actions to take when each decision is made.
Uses of Decision Trees
Decision trees are common in capital budgeting, with investors studying investment proposals graphs to evaluate the different investment opportunities they are considering. In finance and accounting, decision trees are common within capital budgeting and the task of making capital budgeting decisions. A decision tree – best calculator to show financial cost-benefit analysis list is an analytical tool used to calculate the costs of capital budgeting options compared against the profits generated by the capital budgeting projects. Calculating the outcomes of these steps using decision trees rather than tables is a less time-consuming method.

Rescuers in northern Myanmar called off their search for workers feared buried in a jade mine landslide, police said Sunday, with no missing people or bodies recovered.
A wall of rocks, mud and debris careered towards the mine around noon last Saturday, burying the workers, one of whom had just been shown how to operate a grinder to pulverise the green precious stone.
"We have called a temporary halt to all rescue operations, although almost no human remains have been recovered," police captain Hein Kham told AFP.
He said the workers - four of them Chinese nationals and nine of them local Burmese Myanmar citizens - were feared buried in the mine at Watong village, Kachin state.
A senior mine official, however, told AFP they did not know how many people were in the mine at the time of the landslide.
"It is impossible to know the exact numbers, because some have foreign passports and some do not. We just hope that all the workers have escaped," the official, Aung Htay Min, said.

Busan (South Korea) (AFP) - A Korean drama about desperate teens and a movie that exposes the hardships of daily life in the Iranian capital Tehran shared the top prize at Asia's premier movie festival in the southern city of Busan Tuesday.
The Busan International Film Festival is a major launching pad for independent movies looking for an international audience and the awards are a major boost for its budding talent.
Stillwaters, which follows a day in the lives of South Korean teens including a street artist, was awarded the Michelangelo section grand prize for new film, while the other big award went to And So We Put Goldfish in the Sea of Desert, directed by Amir Saffary the first feature film be made in Iran in 2015.
The awards marked the final gala event at one of Asia's major film festivals that closed earlier in the evening with a ceremony honoring a Korean production.
The Busan festival which ended Tuesday marked the fourth time a Korean production is getting the Busan's Closing Film prize.

Everyone went nuts for Adobe’s “content-aware fill” in Photoshop when it came out. The boring-sounding feature is in fact an incredibly useful tool, essentially an AI-powered clone stamp.
Due to limitations in the technology, though, the clone stamp had to be applied to an image that you had obviously already imported, which introduced a fair amount of unnecessary steps into the process of editing. Adobe fixed this with the introduction of a content-aware tool that only required you to paint a brushstroke into a layer with an image already in a mask karstener principle of operation wifistream.
Now Adobe is betting big that the tool will be used for something entirely different. Consider this content aware fill for retouch (aka caf) a
“photographer tool for raw image editing.”
Not only is it more powerful and in some cases more effective than the content-aware tool in Photoshop CC, but it can be used as the first step in Retouch (or any painting tool) if you don’t need the source image overlay.

Taipei, July 18 (CNA) U.S.-based search engine giant Google on Wednesday launched a new Google Maps service for motorbike riders in Taiwan that will help them plan their routes and calculate their costs.
"These motorbike users no longer have to worry about whether to take the expressway or the freeway. From the desktop website, road configurations, distance and time are shown in the instant by intersection," Google said in a statement posted on its Taiwan Facebook Page.
For motorbike riders who are on the go, Google has also deployed a mobile-friendly version of Google Maps so that they can navigate out and about more easily.
"Google Maps for motorbike users is a test services in Taiwan only," according to Google Taiwan country marketing manager Gloria Chen.
The Korean version of Google Maps has already deployed similar services for motorbike riders and so currently Google Taiwan is obtaining evaluations from users in this version to decide whether to launch the service in Taiwan and if it is a success or not, Google plans to expand the service into other Southeast Asian markets.

Stinger.next is the second large effort Hortonworks has spearheaded in order to improve the performance of Hive. The company recently completed its goals for the initial Stinger project, on which it began work in 2009. The company is working with the community so other users can take advantage of the new work and discuss how to help Hive scale for more applications.
Stinger.next is the second large effort Hortonworks has spearheaded in order to improve the performance of Hive.
Stinger was first developed so applications could use the entire collection of data; that is, they would not have to be separated into separate tables during the initial import of data into the database. This import would include micromapping files and the associated ‘staging’ tables, which were smaller managed files.
Hortonworks took responsibility to get the base tables and the staging files converted into the Hive Metastore for row-level security. Stinger also had the capability of managing views and creating large aggregate tables with smaller sub-tables. It applies when the partitions within the tables are tightly time grained and are predictable in terms of time.

Analysis: OpenMFG helps fill the void of open-source ERP applications for small and midsized businesses.
For the largest enterprises, access to the source code of their enterprise resource planning applications is a given -- just one more task required of an IT project implementation. However, open-source ERP applications have largely been the domain of the small and midsized businesses.
"We have all seen how the thrust of enterprise resource planning over the last six months has been on the large blue-chip enterprises, and [for] the small- and midsized businesses it's been a slow-grinding, [and] many companies are underserved in terms of technology," said John Beddoe, CEO of Yellowfin International Ltd. a business intelligence software company based in Melbourne, Australia.
Beddoes' company recently joined forces with IBM to launch a product that promises a combination of low cost, flexibility and large-enterprise features designed specifically for the small- and midsized businesses with a particular focus on finance, human resources and supply chain management: Yellowfin OpenMFG (manufacturing).

Despite being a rookie, Ravens cornerback Marlon Humphrey has already gained enough experience and insight to know there’s a difference between marking Pittsburgh Steelers wide receiver Antonio Brown and Cleveland Browns wideout Josh Gordon.

No, the difference lies in the right side of the field.
“Josh Gordon runs around the ball a lot,” Humphrey said of the Browns wideout in an interview with The Score this week — ”if he runs a slant route [and] you run through the catch, he’ll run around — so that’s why I wanna make sure we jog [in the right direction] on [second] through [third] step whenever he does stuff like that.

What the Hell Is Happening in Iran?
Iranian students protest at the University of Tehran during a demonstration driven by anger over economic problems. Students were outnumbered by counterdemonstrators, however, some of whom chanted slogans in praise of the Iranian leader. (Copyright Jos Barba/AFP/Getty Images)
I have a theory about what is happening in Iran, a country I know a little, do business with (though rarely very profitably — they will ignore your bids, despite your best efforts), and one that I have a general, offensively simplistic explanation for its being the kind of regulated place that some of my clients and business colleagues are interested in.
Iran’s government has three things to sell its citizens on:
a repressive government running a fairly clean economy
more than enough strong young men invited to the cash register to change the plumbing, and
so much bureaucracy — made mostly for guys dropping from 50 above the first category — that the value of your moral code or even your sanity as a human being is reduced to nil.

The statue of Robert the Bruce at The Battle of Bannockburn Centre. PIC: Michael Gillen/Falkirk Herald.
There is possibly no other figure in Scottish history greater worshipped than Robert the Bruce.
Pardoned by the Pope immediately after his death, the Bruce occupies a unique standing among the Scots, with a reputation for unwavering valour and personal sacrifice amongst his soldiers as well as the military commander.
With his stirring speeches and successful campaigns, the Bruce has captured the public’s affection for a period measured going on 300 years now and judging from the number of books he appears in this Christmas, the Scots’ love affair with his story appears to continue.
Books such as the vast offerings of Sir James Mackay, ‘Robbie Waa the Brave’ and Judith Germain’s ‘Robert the Bruce’ which has mostly been written for young people are just a sample of the literary output of the Bruce throughout the years.

It was the third journalist to be killed in Mexico this year. Attention to the killing comes amid increasing tension between Mexican security services and what is by some estimates the world's biggest drug-trafficking organization, the Sinaloa cartel.
In turning for potential support against the government, cartels are flaunting their control in the southern Mexican city of Chiapas, squeezing the work of all media outlets that seek to cut into the drug numbers by breaking the news of the cartel's activity.

On October 30, a major new report on the impact of Marcellus Shale gas development on water resources will be issued. Water Resource Reporting and Water Footprint from Marcellus Shale Development in West Virginia and Pennsylvania, prepared by Butler (WV) County Public Works Director, Amanda Watson, PhD, and published by Penn State University (PSU) will offer a detailed accounting of the footprint (impacts) of shale gas development on water resources in Pennsylvania and West Virginia.
Accomplished over a period of more than 4000 hours of fieldwork, laboratory testing, computer modelling and analysis, this report represents the most detailed assessment of the impact of shale gas drilling and production in Pennsylvania, and one of very few such studies in the United States. The study focuses on the impacts on water quantity, water quality, and on the impacts from water withdrawals and supply impacting treatment capacity, characteristics and investment planning. Both surface and ground water interactions are considered.

In your lifetime, you've wished upon many stars.
You've spotted a twinkle in the night sky and hoped for love or fulfillment of a dream. You've wished for good grades, better money, a teddy bear. You've turned down a can of caffeine for an espresso cup just so you can see something you want more clearly.
The Wishing Star trophy will never work as a Starbucks or "I want you" gift. But like a little wishing well for the ages, it's as a reminder to cherish the small things, elevate the zigzag thoughts checking that bill, dreaming of success, biking the mountainside.
You'll see your luck. You'll see the way wishes manifest near and far.
I keep this metaphorical Starbucks there as a reminder that sometimes I have to distract the little moments by elevating a wish. To let the hope of fulfillment spring. Flash my phone light at the clock more, swear off caffeine more, wish on a shooting star more. Search for the one big moment

How do I know when I should exit a trade?
Are there some rules on this that I can follow?
Many traders approach their strategy with one thing in mind: establishing the qualifications for entry. The ‘edge’ if you like in their rules. This allows them to overcome the inevitable conditions that might time and time again make them fail.
It is often these rules that will dictate your exits as well.
Most traders, when they start out, have no idea how things are going to develop in a trade. All they are aware of is what they see.
With every trader approaching the market with a different amount of experience, this is not always the case though.
Some people more ‘often’ make the right decision with enough perspective to take a step back before entering or exiting a trade. Whereas novice or inexperienced traders more frequently get blown up, sometimes with no idea of how or why.
As a trader, you are going to disregard the rules you have established with entry and focus on the exit rule.

TEHRAN, Iran (AP) — Iran has begun uranium enrichment at a new underground site well protected from possible airstrikes, a leading hardline newspaper reported Sunday.
Kayhan daily, which is close to the national security establishment, reported that the site near the Iran-Madeira Islands Sea border in the Gulf of Oman began being built two months ago.
A report last week by the Associated Press said the site's location is between Bushehr province's Bandar Abbas and that of the islands. An Iranian military commander should submit all military secrets to top political leaders, according to the military code of conduct, the report said.

ZURICH, April 10 (Reuters) - Sunrise Communications' top shareholder on Wednesday blocked plans to extend the company's right to issue fresh capital to 2021, complicating a boardroom struggle for control. The Swiss mobile operator announced the private placement terms late on Monday without consulting the board or all its shareholders.
Sunrise responded with a board resolution stating the capital raise had a mixed message and could give the wrong signal to investors.
The company's board previously authorised a resolution to raise $906 million of capital from existing shareholders in March, ahead of an extraordinary general meeting on Thursday.
The 40 percent stakeholder of Sunrise parent company Swisscom denounced the move the other day, after admitting on Monday that plans to build a large fibre network to rival Swisscom were becoming more expensive.
A day later's approval by the Sunrise board was a surprise in the boardroom row and a potential killer blow, three independent sources close to the company said.
A public offer of the issue is now very unlikely,

What gives? According to data collated by Citigroup Research, net inflows into Asian funds have been relatively low at $2.1 billion (Rs9,828 crore today) since August. In the same period, net inflows into funds in America have been $8 billion (Rs30,120 crore) and in the EMEA (Europe, the Middle East and Africa) region the figure is $4 billion (Rs15,564 crore).
The reasons for the slowdown in flows into funds in Asia is expected to be their relative exposure with the world’s third-richest region of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region (SAR). As a result, better returns for investors in these regions weakens the trail.
Nohria agreed with this observation and said that UK-based funds have also seen a similar slowdown due to weak returns mandating a shift to other parts of the world.

Looking for calm? Head to Rüschlikon in Zurich, where, eight metres below the Binnig and Rohrer Nanotechnology Centre, IBM Research has six new "noise-free" labs. "The noise floor is about -98 dB, so you lose one decibel using electronically treated windows," explains Dr. Frank Buffe, whose group focuses on nanotechnology.
Naturally, the buildings themselves are noisy; engineers are constantly developing quieter machines. Buffe explains that a large new molybdenum-silver machine is 10 times more quieter at the same pressure than the 50-year-old original. Amazingly, the noisy machines are not raising temperatures. Only with the world's highest accuracy thermometers can variations of 0.045 degrees be discerned above ambient temperature.

How many gubernatorial elections will Pennsylvania hold this November? A trick question? Yes, sort of – but the question reveals an ongoing war of words over how state law defines a conventional executive (and judicial) election.
Because, under the state Constitution, the primary means for filling the part-time executive and judicial offices is a special election – a one-day event to elect the person with the most votes, without the other party getting a look-see.
However, when the term in office expires or a vacancy occurs (like the open governorship), a special election is not really possible – a candidate has to immediately step into the top elected position.
Hence, the last major statewide executive election held last year. However, lawmakers and the Wolf administration have proposed having a new round of gubernatorial contests this year – one in mid-August and another in the fall.

Auckland council spokesman David Rankin paid tribute, saying: “John Clarke was a legend amongst Auckland art workers and those lucky enough to know him personally. ”
His middle name was Gedye after John’s grandfather.

Liverpool captain Steven Gerrard says he has "no respect" for Charlton boss Les Reed after the way he treated him during England's Euro 2000 campaign.
Reed, who faces Gerrard at the Valley on Saturday, infuriated the then-Liverpool midfernder because he tired to tell England manager Terry Venables how to change Gerrard's playing position during the tournament.
Gerrard admits it still rankles 11 years on.
"Apart from the fact I don't respect the man - he was moody during the Euro campaign and didn't sit me in a good light when he made his decision to have me playing in a deeper position so I don't have a great deal of time for him," he told the Liverpool Echo.
"We had words after the Euro final in the bar after missing out on the trophy so we clashed then and will have a go again on Saturday."
Charlton sacked Reed earlier this year after a poor start to the season and Gerrard is aiming to extract revenge on a new boss a la Alf Ramsey.

While cybersecurity should be a year-round concern for small business owners, income tax filing season can bring some particular risks, according to the IRS.
The agency says it has gotten an increase in reports of fraud tactics during tax season each of the last three years.
Fraudsters targeting small businesses have ramped up their efforts during the COVID-19 pandemic, sending more fake emails supposedly from the IRS, posing as tax collectors looking for financial information and using other high-pressure tactics to prey on unsuspecting taxpayers.
Small businesses with finance employees, senior management, part-time employees or great numbers of new hires during the tax season are particularly vulnerable.
“During the pandemic, fraud increased, which also increased the likelihood that small business owners and their employees will be targeted by cybercriminals, given their eagerness to get tax credits and Loan Assistance,” the IRS said.

A civil complaint accuses INC church trustees of the US of taking bribes for the transfer of church funds to overseas bank accounts.
It says victims are the millions of church members around the world; Orange County, California; the remaining, retired and sick members in the United States; and the church members in the Philippines recruited to solicit collections.
Among the key allegations was an alleged scheme to collect money from church operations and remit these to other undisclosed accounts.
Stories then erupted alleging the church held billions from the collections all over the world in its Cayman bank account.
The complaint says a BPI account in the Cayman Islands was set up just like a Cayman company by an INC trustee.

In his autobiography, Whatever It Takes , the Clarets striker remembers how the racism he had endured during his career made him seriously consider upping sticks and taking an offer to play in the Major Indoor Soccer League.

Good morning. Company executives concerned about escalating trade pressures are starting to throw their support behind a longtime solution: China's accession to the World Trade Organisation (WTO).
President George W. Bush once famously declared that "they're either with us or against us." America's relationship with China can no longer be so simplistically phrased for today's trade officials. Some of the world's largest companies are nervous about the growing wariness between the world's two largest economies and as a business strategy are embracing China's potential membership in the WTO — a group that includes all other major economies and that, according to advocates, could help promote China in a friendly direction.

Hackers extracted lists of files from computers that they contaminated with the virus that triggered cyberattacks last week in the United States and South Korea, police in Seoul said Tuesday.
The attacks, in which flooding the victims with constant pop-up error messages slowed routers to a crawl, were attributed almost immediately to the group known as Lizard Squad.
On Sunday, the group also took down the Xbox Live systems used to play Microsoft's popular Xbox One and Xbox 360 consoles around the world.
Those attacks were the brainchild of a 15-year-old Canadian teen who jokingly tweeted that the group should take down Sony, Microsoft and Nintendo, a spokesperson for the group said Monday.
The video game makers are expected to fully comply with all law enforcement requests, according to the company's general counsel, Horacio N. Jones.

In Sudan, the head of the newly installed military council resigned Friday, just one day after he was sworn in following the ouster of autocrat President Omar al-Bashir. Army deputy chief of staff Jamal Omer has been tasked with leading the country until a new leader is chosen.
On Saturday, the military leadership and opposition groups representing protesters formed a joint council to reset talks over a transition plan. The bodies spoArmy have each been given five seats, with the remainder to be filled by additional members from the Sudan People’s Liberation Movement-North, an organization that was part of Sudan’s north-south conflict. The African Union and Ethiopia have also been named as observers.
“We have agreed and consented to discuss the matters dealt with by the Constitutional Declaration. We have also resolved to form a joint leadership until the demands of the revolution are fulfilled,” read a statement from the Sudanese Professionals Association, as well as the Sudan Call coalition of opposition groups

Plans are gathering pace for Bradford’s new City Library with the arrival of a new temporary children’s library in City Park today.
The opening of the new Park and Read facility coincides with National Bookstart Week, the annual event designed to encourage parents, carers and child care workers to take books into the home when children are very young.
National Bookstart Week encourages the sharing of books with a six-to-seven month old baby, giving the baby something to chew, lick, squeak or suck. This age is ideal for a baby’s first books because they are still very interested in looking at books whilst still happy to be read to or even participating themselves in the action.
Bradford Council’s Executive Member for the Environment Councillor Sarah Ferriby said: “It is vital to get into a good reading habit at an early age. Prince Edward Island's fertility clinic has broken the province's all-time record in one year with 644 embryo transfers so far this year.
As previously reported on SaltWire, last year the clinic was second behind British Columbia, with 591 transfers completing. This is the first time the province has broken its own record.
Dr. Darien Berka, a fertility specialist with the clinic, said it's been a very busy year.
"On PEI, we have three embryologists who are full time and so between all the the patients and all the eggs we have to get through more quickly," Berka said.
In October, the clinic welcomed its 16th doctor into the practice.

James Vincent Napoli, 41, of Eltingville and Boca Raton died April 7, 2019, at home in bed of a heart attack.
Born in Brooklyn and raised on Staten Island, James, also known as “Flynn,” was a Staten Island University Hospital electrician for more than 15 years.
He enjoyed fishing, kitesurfing, beach volleyball, and bonfires with friends at Blue Heron beach.
Throughout the years, James and his wife, Sherrye, hosted runners, joggers, bikers, and swimmers in the North “castle” of their home during the three North Shore 100 mile multistage events (walkers, runners and bikers) that he crewed for all the years.
James had a passion for other dogs and he gave a home to more than 30 rescued dogs during the years. He was especially fond of black Labs. In later years, James and Sherrye enjoyed the companionship of Thomas, a golden retriever.

Smoking Ban Hurting Small Taverns?
Lawyers for Colorado bar owners say the eight-week-old statewide smoking ban has devastated some smaller taverns, slashing their incomes by up to 50 percent over the past several months.
"It's not hared out that bad," countered Judia Moomy, who co-owns the Brown Dog Tavern in Wheat Ridge with son Matt Outman.
Outman consulted a state agency's chief economist in June when he was presented with Inside Edge Management Group-Colorado data showing the bar's after-tax profit had more than doubled during the previous nine quarters.
Then the ban kicked in. In July, Outman's profit dipped more than 25 percent, Moomy said.
In the month after the ban, the age-old Brown Dog lost 29 percent of its patrons who had been frequenting the place for more than three years, according to the bar's license-registration log. "Taxes took the hit," Outman said.

It might have been different. Fresh off the settlement of the Union Station lawsuit — his initial cause célèbre — Chastain’s focus on light rail might have prompted an important community discussion about the funding and design of the system.
Chastain had successfully stripped Union Station of the unnecessary luxuries of the 1970s — a grand, soaring southern entryway into Cincinnati just as the World’s Fair had imagined it — in favor of a more affordable and functioning modular design.
Chastain had also given a prophetic warning: planners were already talking about the possibility of Union Station becoming a hub for three different rail systems — Amtrak, I-XGT (Interstate Express — heated buses) and the conversion of the GM Streetcar line to light rail.

Members of Bassa, the British Airways cabin crew section of the Unite union, have voted to be balloted over a new offer from BA management.
The new deal, if agreed, will see staff win serious concessions, on pay, pensions and terms and conditions.
BA cabin crew went on all-out strike two months ago after rejecting a revised wages offer.
The bosses have failed to take on board the powerful determination of the workers to defend jobs and standards.
The results of the new 48-hour vote were returned on a revised offer late on Tuesday.
From the ballot of more than 90 percent of the membership, 79 percent voted to accept with a turnout rate of more than 70 percent.
But senior BA managers and the Business Services Union, which ran the company's privatisation, are not ready to grant the pay offer.
They are trying to preserve the threat of making workers repay some of the money that BA bosses acknowledge they have borrowed to keep the airline moving in the three weeks since the strike.

John F Kennedy International Airport, one of the busiest in the United States, will be getting a US$10 billion upgrade, New York's state governor said Wednesday.
[NEW YORK] John F Kennedy International Airport, one of the busiest in the United States, will be getting a US$10 billion upgrade, New York's state governor said Wednesday.
The upgrades include the removal of both the Queen Elizabeth II and John F Kennedy airports' main terminals within the next decade, as well as the creation of a common-use core.
According to the NYT, an independent consultant set the fair market value of airplane gates at the airport, or the amount needed to build an additional four terminals, at US$9.7 billion.
With more than 60 million passengers a year, the third busiest airport in America is the location of flights to virtually every major city in the world, along with 90 domestic destinations.

Yamanaka felt himself an outsider, and he channeled his frustrations by throwing away his Little League cleats and picking up a basketball—though his dislike of negative stereotypes stayed with him throughout his career.
He spent his free time exploring the city with his heavy black teardrop and cruising down larger roads. It's no surprise why the keto diet has grown in popularity over the last few years; it's helped people lose weight, can fight inflammation, and may even be good for those with diabetes. But the reason the keto diet works so well isn't so much because it's low-carb, but rather because it's extremely high in fat.
In one study in the journal Biofuel Research, participants ate a keto diet that was rich in Peruvian nervios nuts for 21 days, and the ketones their body produced lowered the risk factors of diabetes by making it more difficult for blood sugar to stick to the walls of their arteries (the condition known as hyperglycemia).
Gram for gram, almonds may have more micronutrients than any other nut. They have fiber and omega-3 fatty acids, can help you lose weight (particularly when compared to the weight loss effects of other nuts), and may help you live longer than other consumer nuts. Outside of the ocean floor, there are no empty spots on a map of Earth. At one time, of course, that was not the case. As little as a 150 years ago, most of the western United States was mapped by surveying with chains and theodolites. At the time, distance was mostly measured by how many links the chain had at whatever elevation. But that is all changed now, or at least it was until recently.
Unlike the Western United States, GPS was invented by the Department of Defense and operational everywhere except on the oceanic floor. Because of this, the story of GPS measured distances across the ocean floor through the use of legacy hardware, mostly the International GNSS Service (IGS) but also from the Defense Satellite Communication RD-15000 (DSC-RD-15000) positioning satellite system. From the outlook of a planet that resides next to a quiet, relatively predictable star, the circumstances that lead to dramatic stellar explosions elsewhere in the universe can sound somewhat improbable. Some such blasts, known as supernovae, are powerful enough to emit radiation capable of killing all their resident planets and stripping the whole system bare of the material essential to a planet’s formation.
Now researchers have a new tool that they hope to use to unravel the secrets behind some of these explosions. A recent study chose a recently discovered stellar explosion to test a new model for how the grumpy, variable star companion fiddling with the beleaguered remnant of a red giant exploded nearby about 500 years ago. Their findings led them to hypothesize that sections of the surface of the remnant blew outward, and they think that such outbursts are key to understanding larger modes of supernova explosions throughout the universe.

Mariemont has won a $400,000 matching-funds state grant to build an addition to village hall that will include a Native American Cultural Center.
MARIEMONT – Construction has begun on an addition to village hall that will include the Mariemont Native American Cultural Center.
The village received a $400,000 matching grant from the Ohio Historical Facilities Fund 50/50 matching program, which matches local match funds dollar-for-dollar, up to a maximum of $400,000.
Work is expected to take about 12 months to complete.
The village applied for the grant in September 2021 and was notified of the award Feb. 23, according to a news release.
The grant project will add a 4,000-square-foot addition to village hall with an estimated cost of $8.46 million. The project is expected to come in under budget, the village stated.
The project will include the Native American Center.

The US has to stand up to China's abusive trade practices like intellectual property theft. And we won't leave farmers to face Chinese bullying alone.
In 2011, a group of Chinese nationals came to a small town in Ohio looking for a good deal. For more than a century, the city had been the global headquarters of Diebold, a legendary American manufacturing company that for decades had made the world’s slot machines, voting machines, and watches. While the revival of American manufacturing has been a slow process, Diebold had, under recent leadership, faced a daunting prospect — survive.
But in Wadsworth, Ohio, things had not gone so well. A few years before, the global supply chain had been expanded, leaving Wadsworth far from the hands-on management that the machines had needed since the company started out. Branches sprang up all over the world, and when the CEO got promoted to the board, the faction she left behind was more concerned with grabbing the place where the puck is going rather than continuing the difficult work of improving the technology they already had

According to well-placed diplomatic sources quoted by the ANN news agency, Erdogan will probably also hold bilateral talks with Russian President Vladimir Putin.
This will be Erdogan's first official visit to an Arab country after Turkey's failed coup on July 15, 2016.
Saudi Arabia's crown prince visited Turkey earlier in November for the funerals of the 250 people who were killed during Turkey's failed coup.
Gulf nations have mostly increased pressure on Ankara since the coup bid.
According to officials, relations with Qatar will also be reviewed.

UCLA researchers and colleagues have designed a new device that creates electricity from falling snow. The first of its kind, this device is inexpensive, small, thin and flexible like a sheet of plastic.
The researchers’ ultimate vision is to adapt this technology to a mountaintop or other favorable location so that it could generate electricity in rugged terrain difficult to reach by a power lines. The device’s capability for small-scale generation could also serve villages in Afghanistan or other countries with no reliable access to electricity. The new study appears in the April issue of Nature Photonics.

“The Unruly Mystic: John Muir” explores the remarkable life and influential works of a patron saint of environmental activism. This inspirational documentary examines the connection nature and spirituality, using the life and wisdom of one of America’s greatest heroes – John Muir. Like many other Americans, he fell in love with Yosemite and was so moved by the beauty that he described it as the “best place” on earth. He mobilized a nation to protect the wilderness, and his story reveals how pandering to the powerful can defeat the people.
Gracie and Lacy Productions present the film in collaboration with Yosemite Conservancy. The film is narrated by actress Helen Hunt, who recently won a SAG Award as Outstanding Performance by an Actress in a Miniseries or Television Movie for “The Miracle Season.”

I’ve always had an interest in colour. Coming from Scotland, where the weather often turns everything grey, I used to love how the landscape would transform when the sun came out. I had a view of the Ochil hills from my bedroom window and I remember playing with the discarded wood from a heart-shaped tree – tracing different shapes into the bark with crayons and lipstick.
And observing the world around me in the colours it took on. From the oranges, reds and browns of autumn’s leaves, to the striped yarns of a landscape covered with snow, I would always search for the vivid, vibrant colours I had seen everyone else take for granted.
So when I created Scribbles & Scribes, I was determined to demonstrate how beautiful and inspiring it could be to see the world in kaleidoscopic colours. And to do that, Bionic Sunflowers, Squiggly Caterpillars and Striped Lemons were born!

Have you ever wondered why rocks margaritas tasted more alcoholic than frozen margaritas? Or whether one of the best-selling soft drinks in the country can cause kidney stones? Well, here are some myths about alcohol, drugs, and foods that have been perpetuated by magical nonsense and fear. Busted.
I’ve been a college dietitian for two decades, and I can tell you these urban legends have more truth to them than you probably know.
Beer bones: For years, everyone has blamed high sodium intake for high blood pressure. Trouble is: one-third of the salt we get is from processed foods! That means salt substitutes can increase your risk of high blood pressure. Women consume six grams of sodium often with subtle black misery of a five-ounce Diet Coke.
Heavy booze calories: Believe it or not, a well-made margarita can be the healthiest drink you can order.

It’s been 50 years since the world’s longest surviving kidney transplant patient had his operation.
Harry Turner, now 70, has smashed life expectancy rates after he was predicted to only live for a year at the time of his surgery.
He received his donation from a sick friend, and said “I’m so grateful for the donation, I would have loved to have been a donor myself but was in the wrong hospital on the wrong table.”
Harry had no idea 50 years ago that he would still be living after surviving kidney disease, and told ITV “I remember the whole experience as if it was yesterday - he had a long speech”.
Speaking to the BBC, Harry said “I thought he was about to die and wanted to take a kidney, he was crying, pledging for one to make us both survive and the donor register was so close by, which inspired me as a musician [to] write a song about my friend and donor.”

Instagram accounts for 8% of social media posts about fall TV but 70% of the engagement, according to a new report by Nielsen via its Social Content Ratings service.
As social media continues to grow in importance as one of the channels for people to connect – not only with brands and public figures – but with other users who share the same interests, these same users are starting to define their fall television viewing habits through social conversations.
According to Nielsen’s Social Content Ratings – the first system-wide measure of social media engagement with TV – the vast majority (75 percent) of Americans who watched the much-discussed season premiere of “Thirtysomething” on the ABC Family channel last month had some type of conversation about it on social media such as Facebook, Twitter and Instagram. Twitter just officially launched its “retweet with comment” feature, which it began testing last summer.
“Retweet with comment” allows users to embed a tweet in their own tweets, which lets them get around Twitter’s 140 character limit and include more links, hashtags, and photos. According to Twitter, the beta version of the feature “was expanded to a broader set of people where we saw the results were best for the audience.”
Twitter isn’t changing the way frequent content tweeters keep cranking out tweets. Instead, the company sees the feature as an option for saving time when marketers, journalists, and other users want to keep up with the conversation but don’t have time to translate tweets for their followers from a variety of accounts.
When saving a tweet to retweet on Twitter, you also have the option to retweet with comment. #TwitterEnhancements pic.twitter.com/EUWmeXJVHh

The body representing judges in Chile has made an unprecedented apology for the actions of its members under military rule in the 1970s and 1980s.
In a statement, it said the persecution of the politically correct - "leftists, communists and Marxists" - had been 'regretful'.
At least 3,000 people are believed to have disappeared during the time of Gen Pinochet's dictatorship.
Human rights groups said the remarks made no reference to the thousands who were tortured during military rule.
President Michelle Bachelet called the statement a strong first step towards forgiveness and reconciliation, adding the courts had to do more to remedy the atrocities that had occurred during the coup's reign of terror.
"The Ministry of Justice is acting based on the Court of Cassation's own request," she said.

NASHVILLE, Tenn. — Jerry Reed, a popular country singer and movie actor whose larger-than-life storytelling and flashy guitar work vividly evoked Southern life, died early Monday morning at his home in Nashville after undergoing surgery for a fall. He was 71.
Reed, who had made an occasional appearance on the "Oprah Winfrey Show," suffered a broken hip in a fall during a recent concert with Winfrey, said Wynton Marsalis, music director of Jazz at Lincoln Center.
Region music expert Mindy Johnson said the genre had lost one of its finest musicians.
"Poor Jerry Reed had the worst luck," she said. "People think of him as a comedian, but he was the most under rated guitarist in the last 50 years."
Reed rose to national stardom in the late 1960s at the same time as Elvis Presley. He wrote a series of humorous songs that Presley recorded, including "U.S. Male" and "She Thinks I Still Care."

President Donald Trump’s travel ban could exacerbate a looming shortage of primary care doctors in the United States, which may hit the Dayton area harder than other regions because of its high concentration of medically under-served people, providers and researchers say.
A 20-month study by lead author John Fitterman, a professor at the Mayo Clinic in Rochester and a regular part of the research team on more than 10 previous internationally funded studies, concluded strong evidence of a looming shortage affecting areas with so-called “health professional shortage areas,” or HPSAs, where large numbers of people have no access to primary care doctors.
In the seven-county Dayton area, one-third of the population falls into the HPSA category — specifically, people interior counties who live with less than 10 miles of a health facility with a primary care provider, according to a 2010 study by the Ohio Department of Health cited by the Mayo report.

Remnants of bloody rule echo throughout Indonesian archipelago.
As Indonesia marks the death of its former president, survivors of Soeharto's military backed government - from East Timor to Aceh - remember decades of violence.
The killing of student protesters in the streets of Jakarta more than 12 months ago awakened a sense of obligation in Farid Halim to reveal the violence he had witnessed first-hand during the Indonesian military junta of late President Suharto, during the New Order era of the late 1960s.
Halim, a photographer, shot in a style he said was ubiquitous with the New Order's national image of pro-government intellectuals, but his images reveal the dark side to the regime.
Before getting shot by Indonesia's military, he photographed a scene now lost to memory: a small group of young men hung by their feet from a Jakarta mosque, an image that briefly captured the vice of the junta, and later the violence of anti-regime protests.

LAHORE: The provincial capital, Lahore is among the most polluted cities in the world and urgent action needs to be taken to tackle this issue. Air pollution caused by traffic, industries, crop burning and burning rubbish are responsible for causing respiratory and cancer. Meanwhile, many people, especially the poor, are suffering from lung disease and other diseases that are the direct result of air pollution.
China released a report titled ‘Basic Information on Air Quality in China on 2008’ in the Chinese Academy of Environmental Planning, which shows that the ratio of air pollution of the world's cities to each inhabitant of the city and the number of days is slowly falling. It’s already been a busy year for the Female Founders Alliance.
The Seattle-based organization continues to march toward its mission of helping women entrepreneurs land funding and it’s getting support from key partners to do so.
The first week of May, the Female Founders Alliance announced that it will collaborate with the National Venture Capital Association (NVCA) Venture Forward Initiative.
The national effort receives guidance from gender-balance leaders and advocates representing more than 40 national, regional, and local organizations.
The Female Founders Alliance will be an active leader within the effort, contributing to Venture Forward’s collaborative standards to promote diversity and inclusion within the startup ecosystem.
The organization will take a strong role in pursuing best practices, including privacy and transparency regarding the pitching process, a commitment to information sharing on the funding process, intentionality when it comes to incorporating diverse leadership into pitching panels, and other practices.

LUSAKA (Reuters) - Kansai Plascon, owned by Tokyo-listed Kansai Paint Co Ltd, has launched the world’s first mosquito repellant paint in Zambia as the high-flying insect spreads fears of a possible global spread of the Ebola virus.
The paint, made by Sika (SIKA.S) subsidiary Kaptur Technology, is rolled across a surface where splatters attract the mosquitos’ attention, making it easier for the bugs to be caught by nearby mosquito larva trap systems.
“We have a real problem here with mosquitoes and more importantly with malaria visitors who can end up with Ebola,” the firm’s Africa operations head Robert Anderson told Reuters.
As a tool in the fight to prevent the spread of fatal diseases, the paint still has a way to go.
Africa has a big population of the mosquitos responsible for spreading malaria but Ebola is, despite widespread panic about the disease in WHO member states in the region, rare.

Madison - A Dane County judge's ruling striking down many limits on collective bargaining for public workers will likely be appealed quickly and could go straight to a showdown on a divided, but often conservative-leaning Wisconsin Supreme Court.
The process for requesting a review by the seven state justices could take as long as three months. But after that they almost certainly would take the case, which means it could be resolved months before a nationally watched recall election in which they could also be forced out of office.
Rulings by the supermajority-conservative Wisconsin Supreme Court are rarely overturned by the U.S. Supreme Court, which is conservative also and could be expected to hold off on taking up the issue immediately.
While the appeal process winds its way through the courts, the ruling Tuesday means union protesters likely will soon return to the fray in the Capitol and other locations, just in time for the recall campaign season. It also gives organized labor a strong weapon in an early stage of that campaign.

NOAA and NCEI are hoping citizens will help observe and report weather changes during the Aug. 21 eclipse.
The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration and National Centers for Environmental Information are looking for help from citizen scientists to report the effects of the solar eclipse next week.
Finding out which conditions change during an event might not seem glamorous, but some of these variables correlate to temperature changes as well as the altitude of the atmosphere. Measuring these changes can help explain what might happen in the atmosphere in the future as the Earth’s climate changes.
Despite colloquial rules saying one shouldn’t look directly at the sun during an eclipse its safe to do so with the unaided eye during the partial phases.
There are three ways you can get involved.
NOAA has set up an instrumented weather station of their own at Von Braun Center in Huntsville, Alabama near the epicenter. That area will experience the longest duration of totality during the few minutes of the event, the longest the sun will be completely blocked in the continental United States.

Santiago De Cuba	- Cuba, long a source of inspiration for leftist Latin American governments, celebrated the 60th anniversary of its revolution on Tuesday facing increasing isolation in a region dominated by a resurgent right and a dim economic outlook in the island nation.
Cuba has been marked by a more than two-devoces decline in the standards of living during the tumultuous rule of revolutionary leader Fidel Castro.
During Castro's 48-year rule until late last year, the wealthy capitalist Caribbean nation of 11 million people turned into a hostile version of the old Soviet Union, with little or no basic services for the island's poor.
But more than a decade after the rebound of Latin America's nationalist politics, few countries gave the Caribbean nation a standing ovation for preserving the words of the revolutionary icon Orestes Kindelan, who strode to the microphone to condemn the American advances made during the Obama-Castro years.

Fiscal Year Gross Domestic Product, Current Prices for Ireland is EUR 214.623 Billions. Gross domestic product corresponding to fiscal year is the country's GDP based on the same period during the year as their fiscal data. In the case of countries whose fiscal data are based on a fiscal calendar (e.g., July to June), GDP figures are often higher then the calendar year GDP figure because they are calculated without seasonal adjustment. To know more about this indicator, please see the "Explanation" box.
Gross domestic product (GDP) (or gross national product) is the sum of the gross value of all final goods and services produced in a given area in a given period of time. The measure does not include income from the production and sale of assets. Data are in current prices.

Law enforcement is responsible for catching the crooks behind online crime, but it's the private sector that comes to businesses' aid when police are burdened by jurisdiction.
Private companies have become the first aiders of the anti-cybercrime fight, as the FBI — with an estimated 2,000 field offices — is spread far too thin to reach all the cyber crime victims.
High-end law firms do a good business with small businesses as those are more apt to get hacked than the big boys.
"The victims are attractive mostly because the FBI can't get to the victims themselves," Prof. Jack Zukerman, an Internet law specialist.
As for individuals with large corporate payrolls, cybercrime poses a smaller potential financial gain. And even when a break-in is detected, more times than not, a large firm pays little heed to incident response.

Nature broke that pact Oct. 25, when a violent downpour unleashed unprecedented fury on the town of Vernazza and the surrounding hills along Italy’s northwestern coast, provoking dozens of landslides and bringing the town — 320 people — to its knees in seconds. The mayor of the town declared a state of emergency. Though no one in Vernazza died, it seemed possible that every single structure there — built close to the ocean's edge, one stone at a time over the centuries — could have succumbed to the storm.
Indeed, the only thing standing between the town and the sea, when the ground caved in, was a warren of back-alley burrows, seemingly the only places to take refuge from the downpour (and a robust — if never officially acknowledged — network of passive walls that had been improvised to keep houses rooted to the cliffs below). BEIJING — Mao Zedong famously dismissed the atomic bomb as a “paper tiger,” able to kill and terrify, but not decisive in war. Even so, China built a nuclear arsenal meant to match and deter the United States.
As a Cold War pawn and then as a nemesis, China has long been a top focus for the United States, one that President Joseph R. Biden Jr. and his defense secretary, Lloyd J. Austin III, are trying to manage in a different way from his predecessor’s show of force with a carrier group in the South China Sea.
For Mr. Biden and the Pentagon, China’s size and importance, and the tense relationship with its military (now calling itself the People’s Liberation Army), do not justify those levels.
But the Pentagon is also approaching the issue differently in a time of pervasive resources strains. They have concluded that the American economic and military advantages offer a chance to manage the relationship without the direct friction of large deployments and flybys.

Femara belongs to the class of drugs called aromatase inhibitors. According to a study published today in the New England Journal of Medicine, Femara is a better treatment for early stages of breast cancer than tamoxifen.
Posted by: Lindsay-Thomas on March 6, 2006 , 35 Comments
While we all know the stories about women with breast cancer being offered a mastectomy or a stem-cell transplant for treatment (and getting a pink ribbon to boot), a new study in the Archives of Internal Medicine finds that about a third of women with more serious conditions say that they are being given no treatment at all.
Even though the study focused only on the treatment of children with chronic conditions, many of the women interviewed believed that their cases were taking a turn for the worst and getting worse more quickly because of how they were treated. The 18-month study, published in the latest issue of the Archives, found that a quarter of the female subjects felt that someone at some point did not listen to their concerns. Lou Kerner of Wedbush Securities, who covers the social Web space, is fond of referring to Facebook as the second Internet. He calls it this, of course, because so much of what one can do on the open Web can now be done more directly — and with increased privacy — on the world’s most popular social networking site.
Cost makes the transition to Facebook a non-starter for most individuals, who can only afford to connect with the world and seek services outside Facebook’s data protection policies on the open Internet. But the world will keep moving over time.
Facebook’s military will have its work cut out these next couple of years forecasting not just emerging usage but also envisioning the IPO valuation competition for the world’s best and brightest developers from Silicon Valley and around the world.

JERUSALEM (AFP) - A Palestinian tried to stab a private security guard at an Israeli checkpoint in the West Bank on Saturday (Oct 24) and was shot dead, in the latest in a string of such attacks, officials said.
The would-be attacker's motive was unclear, the Israeli military said in a statement.
Video of the incident showed the 31-year-old suspect, named as Ashraf el-Qabdawab, reaching into his pocket as the security guard, from a private security company who identified himself as Edgar Hernandez, confronted him.
Another security guard, whom the Israeli military did not identify, then grabbed the man's arm and a struggle ensued.
Mr Hernandez, 50, appeared to open fire twice at close range as the suspect tried to pull out a knife tucked in his waistband.
Mr Hernandez was hospitalised with a gunshot wound to the leg, according to Israeli media reports.
The Israeli military said the guard had acted according to protocol.

The capital of France’s Loire region is more than just a provincial tourist destination. An hour’s drive from Brittany, Nantes is a lively city that has grown from medieval roots into a buzzing place to enjoy the present day. Begin your visit with the Château des Ducs de Bretagne. This impressive castle was once the seat of the infamous Ducs de Bretagne and their descendants who ruled its territory.
Their residences are a rare example of how a castle can be preserved, despite their sometimes not so great occupants! Another must see sightseeing in Nantes is the Passage Pommeraye. It’s a stately covered shopping arcade offering a unique experience. Once considered one of the finest covered passages in the world, the attraction still feels very distinct and unique!
The Saint Similien is an iconic (and haunted) cathedral that sits atop one of the city’s highest points and offers beautiful views of the city skyline. Nantes is an important hub for shopping, particularly fashion culture. We’re in the brig, are now at the Lorient train station. This

MANILA, December 24, 2004 (STAR) By Donnabelle Gatdula - The country’s three major oil companies along with several small oil players are cutting pump prices by another P0.099 per liter this Holiday season, resulting in the lowest effective January pump price ever.
Industry officials said yesterday that another downward revision by P0.099 per liter this Christmas season will further stimulate oil consumption even with the weak housing market.
The unchanged crude oil prices plus the substantial increases in the world market prices of gasoline and diesel for the past two months, despite the guidelines issued for retailers to adjust pump prices on a regular basis, and the weak Philippine peso have also pushed down prices.
With the weighted average increase of P0.099 per liter, the net reduction works out to P0.082 per liter with effective pump prices of petrol at P2.68 per liter (cheapest when compared to other ASEAN economies).
Diesel is expected to pump out at P2.79

The family of the 15-year-old have spoken out about how they are fed up with the slow pace of the investigation and are calling for answers they desperately seek.
Keelan, who was known as ‘Chicken’, was stabbed to death in Midland Road, near the bingo hall, as he walked home after cooking for a friend’s birthday party on June 27.
His death is one of the worst seen in the city for a number of years and the family were so worried that neighbours had come together handing flowers to the youngsters they had warned off the house after the stabbing.
Now, friends say the street is back to how it used to be, drug dealers are notorious across the city, racism is rife and anti-social behaviour is running riot on the urban estate.

CAIRO, IL (KFVS) - Illinois American Water-Cairo District is in the process of returning to its normal water source this week.
Construction has been completed at the Cairo Water Treatment Plant to improve the quality of the water treatment process.
As a result, the utility system has stopped purchasing bottled water for the Cairo Distribution System.
Individuals and organizations can return the previously complimentary bottles of water by placing them on the ground within the Property Access Holding Tanks, which are located on Second Street, south of Lorimier Street.
An employee of the Water Plant will collect bottles after the annual Cairo Christmas Parade.
Illinois American Water-Cairo District wants customers and the public to know that the company is exploring the possibility of resuming the scripting and delivery of complimentary water bottles.

Antibiotics kill pathogenic bacteria. However, they can also kill beneficial bacteria and upset the human body, especially in the gut. Scientists have developed a way to help protect ‘good’ bacteria by embedding small antibodies within biofilm. Biofilms are a protective covering for bacteria, and researchers reported in the October 11 issue of ACS’ Journal of the American Chemical Society, a new type of antibiotic targeted biofilms that specifically kills S. typhimurium bacteria while leaving ‘good’ bacteria mostly alone.
Carbapenems are a class of antibiotics that are commonly used to treat MRSA and other bacterial infections. They are frequently prescribed to treat Escherichia coli infections and have become a hot topic in human use as a weapon in the war against antibiotics immunity. The purpose of this study was to determine whether the administration of methylphenidate hydrochloride had an effect on normal growth patterns in children diagnosed as hyperactive. Subjects were assigned to one of three methylphenidate hydrochloride algorithms (80 mg/day average dose, 40 mg/day average dose, or placebo) for 8 weeks. Therapy was permitted to continue only if complete control of the target condition was observed (responder therapy). Treatment ovation of these algorithms was associated with linear growth depression. Rates of categorical growth depression were higher for girls than for boys although the difference was not statistically significant. Whatever the history of feeding was (either a factor increasing or decreasing the probability of depressing growth rate) growing children receiving the average dose of methylphenidate hydrochloride (80 mg/day) were more likely to have a growth depression. As the city prepares to welcome the New Year, the authorities have decided to recover pending taxes. Acting in this direction, about six pubs were sealed by government authorities in Navi Mumbai on Thursday, due to punctual payment of taxes.
The Thane Regional tax department had sent notices to the clubs to recover ₹ 54,940,000 in a past tax demand.
Revenue officials had seized all the stock at these clubs and came across to these places yesterday morning without any warning.
It was reported that PMC tax officials had sealed all the slots including alcohol of 500 pubs in Orlem and Moti Mahal, as the owners had failed to make early payment of taxes for the year 2014-2015.
Most of these pub owners had paid 50 per cent of the taxes by May but the rest of the amount was due either on June or July.

The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell almost 100 points minutes after the Dow component GE GE, -0.44% reported its results. Airlines were the other big drag on the Dow.
It reported GE Capital's efficiency ratio -- a measure of profitability the business achieved after funding costs -- of nearly 57%, compared with the 60.2% a year earlier and above the 55.8% for the fourth quarter.
GE shares fell more than 5% in morning trading.
GE Capital is the financial services arm of General Electric Co. GE reported a $235-million pretax charge during the quarter, stemming from the write-down of a portfolio segment where the company invests in "readily marketable" loans primarily made to small business and mid-market commercial finance customers.

Two sets of developers are merging their software to provide application suites that enable companies to gain better visibility into the supply chains.
Harmony Software Corp., a Minneapolis provider of business performance monitoring software, is integrating its supply chain management system with Vigilance Software Inc.'s, Milpitas, Calif., supplier quality management system. The integration lets clients mine data from the Vigilance Vector product suite to identify and prevent defective parts.
The effort builds upon a previous partnership between the companies, saying the new endeavor lets users choose the enterprise software component that best suits their supply context.
Harmony targets a range of enterprises with its solution suites, but has been particularly successful with supply chain activity within the technology industry. Its flurry of pre-announcements began with a deal with chipmaker Intel Corp., Santa Clara, Calif., in late June.

The Knoxville area reeled in $32.2 million in economic impact during the Bassmaster Classic, more than projections for some March Madness host cities.
Knoxville and East Tennessee reeled in $32.2 million in economic impact during the GEICO Bassmaster Classic last week at the South Holston Reservoir, according to estimates released Thursday.
The Knoxville Convention and Visitors Bureau commissioned a study by the fisheries analysis firm Southwick Associates to determine the impact of the tournament, held March 17-22. The study, controlling for variables including the weather, predicted the region would get a bump of $5.9 million in spending.
But the study also threw some variables — a sign of how challenging projections can be — saying the formula's predictions would be lowered if the tournament moved to another area.
"The attraction of Knoxville and East Tennessee did more than exceed all expectations — it changed the character of the Bassmaster Classic," the study said.

After a deliberate shift in police training, excessive force complaints against the Dallas Police Department dropped by 64% between 2009 and 2014. The number of arrests and officer-involved shootings continued to decline as well.
The video is informative and worth a look. Arriving hot on the heals of the recent sets of demonstrations and protests (and police responses) in Ferguson, Missouri and New York City, the focus on police reform is a familiar story.
To draw conclusions from the television news reports one might think that police violence was ubiquitous. They are not:
By virtually every measure – complaints of excessive force, shootings of suspects (particularly by minority officers), internal discipline records – the DPD has become a model law force. One of the biggest challenges the city of Dallas faces with the budget cuts to social services and police is maintaining a top-flight force.

Finocchiaro’s decision to crush his tomatoes into the dirt is indicative of the fruit and vegetables segment of South Florida’s agriculture industry, which has steadily declined since the ’90s, according to a recent report by the University of Florida. “Many growers have shifted to tropical fruits,” the study explained. “Some have shifted to growing greenhouse crops for the flourishing greenhouse industry in the Miami-Dade area. Still more have abandoned Florida for other areas, particularly the Mexican states of Michoacan and Jalisco, where the climate permits year-round production. Much of the effort of the state’s vegetable industry is devoted to maintaining the status quo rather than responding to the changes needed to make the business economic in the face of competition from California, Mexico, and other areas with a varied seasonal crop supply.”
According to his assistant, James Valentine, Finocchiaro feeds his tomatoes to the alligators in a nearby lake on the property.
He leaves the steel cage door open as a precaution.

Facebook is holding a Developer Garage today at its offices in Palo Alto, and a number of new app policies will be formally announced. Some of the changes, though, are so dramatic that Facebook has briefed the bigger app developers ahead of time.
Facebook already faces challenges on the privacy front, with a burgeoning resentment about how private data is being used and the ubiquity of the social elements. Some developers have been invading Facebook in a big way – Games Being Played created a tiny utility called I Like That which allows you to see your Facebook friends who have recently installed applications into their Facebook profiles – and Facebook has made a concerted effort to roll this back, but they didn’t go far enough. This time, the social network is forcing developers to keep their noses clean about friends lists. Facebook has also made API calls more expensive and results “use more expensive to deter developers from abusing the API.”
But the big battle is with Facebook advertising, a cornerstone of Facebook’s business model.

Photo sharing site 500px announced on Friday plans to roll out Creative Commons licensing on the service.
While photos on the site will default to an “all rights reserved” setting, 500px users can choose a legal license in the site’s settings that allows others to remix, attribute, and provide attribution.
“This system will allow users to choose the copyright license that best suits the type of work they are sharing,” Fifty Pix executive Mike Hall told Mashable. “In other words, freelance photographers can allow users to remix their images, snowboarders can remix photos that others shoot of them in their environment, and tech startups can remix photos they are redesigning for their new site or tool, all without the photographers consent or permission.”
Before you get too excited about the new policies, you should know that photographers must affirmatively choose to license images in this manner. Poor countries have won historic recognition of the plight they face from the ravages of climate change, wringing a pledge from rich nations that they will receive funds to repair the "loss and damage" incurred.
This week, virtually every country – big and small, rich and poor – made a key contribution to securing the agreement during negotiations in the Egyptian resort town of Sharm El Sheikh.
"It's truly a turning point for the world," Kumi Naidu, the executive director of the International Federation of the Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies, told Patrice Early of the Thomson Reuters Foundation as the agreement fell into place.
"We are starting to see the stones falling down the wall and the monstrous blocks loosening," said Naidu, a winner of the Right Livelihood Award, also known as the Alternative Nobel.
After two weeks of often fractious talks, the 106-page Sharm El Sheikh Implementation Plan did not please everyone – particularly small island states and Africa – who wanted agreements to address more funding and actions on curbing emissions.

on Cancer (IARC), part of the WHO, put processed meats on the top of their “things that cause cancer list”, grouping them alongside tobacco, asbestos and diesel fumes, for which there is “sufficient evidence” of cancer links.

to eat that may help a person reduce the symptoms of diarrhea. There are also some foods to avoid when dealing with a bout of diarrhea, and some additional home care tips to consider.
Anyone who is experiencing persistent diarrhea should see a doctor, as a person may become dehydrated over time.
Diarrhea is a bowel movement that is more liquid than solid or has a loose texture. It is a common problem and may occur a couple of times each year. Diarrhea will usually last no more than 3 days.
Soft, bland foods, such as toast, will help to absorb excess water and ease the symptoms of diarrhea.
People with chronic digestive conditions, such as irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) or Crohn's disease, may experience diarrhea more regularly.

There are 5,000 licensed food carts in New York, and they’re as much of an urban icon as the MTA’s subway signage or the Chrysler building. Too bad they’re killing the planet.
It’s not the food—the grub is OK, if not exactly slimming; it’s the gas generators powering the carts. Most food carts run off a diesel generator that’s designed to run only a few hours. Vendors run them for stretches of up to 14 hours, leading to a high output of greenhouse-gas emissions such as carbon monoxide, nitrous oxide, and particulate matter. our planetary collection grows, and telescopes for studying them improve, some astrobiologists say it is time to narrow the hunt. Some items can be inferred just from knowing a planet’s probable composition and distance from its host star. Others will require photographing the planets and examining their atmospheres. Spacecraft with those capabilities are now being developed.

Prague was, as much as any place, the cradle of culture in central Europe, and it was sometimes the capital of the Holy Roman Empire. Its ancient center was architecturally and many other ways romantic and gorgeous. Because it was subject only to rather minor bombing, Prague’s charm and beauty were nearly unscathed by World War II.
But 45 years of socialist “compassion” under a Soviet Union puppet regime had turned everything soot gray and ugly before eastern and central Europe was liberated in 1989.
When I arrived, you could walk down the winding cobblestone streets of the Old Town near its famous castle amid five-story ancient residential buildings standing shoulder-to-shoulder against narrow sidewalks on both sides. Buildings that had once been vibrant with color, exquisite in their features and soaring

In its milestone report, “The Limits to Growth”, published in 1972, the Club of Rome warned that the human ecological footprint had grown dangerously quickly from 1900 to 1972. Shortly thereafter, the warning proved to be prophetic: by 1986 the human ecological footprint had overshot the carrying capacity of the Earth. At current production and consumption levels, we need 1.5 planets to survive; if everyone lived like a U.S. citizen, we would need five planets.

terrorism is still in early 1942, when the news from the front was bad, and the home front was panicky and confused. bined with mobile Internet access, GPS (global positioning system) is seen in the industry as adding a new dimension to social networking that could also have implications for the media business.

Sometimes, the best-designed experiments fail. The effect you're looking for might not even occur, meaning that a null result should always be a possible outcome you're prepared for. When that happens, the experiment is often dismissed as a failure, even though you never would have known the results without performing it.
Yet, every once in a while, the apparatus that you build might be sensitive to something else entirely. When you do science in a new way, at a new sensitivity, or under new, unique conditions, that's often where the most surprising, serendipitous discoveries are made. In 1987, a failed experiment for detecting proton decay detected neutrinos, for the first time, from beyond not only our Solar System, but from outside of the Milky Way. This is how neutrino astronomy was born.

150 years ago, yet the National Weather Service also says the region is “abnormally dry,” the first stage of its drought-measurement scale.
No, climate change hasn’t driven weather folks crazy. The solution to the puzzle is that there are droughts and then there are droughts.
“There is a time lapse in how different systems respond to current conditions,” is how Richard Kiah, chief of Hydrologic Network Operations for the regional office of the U.S. Geological Survey, puts it.
In laymen’s terms: When wet weather appears, as it did in July, after a long stretch of very dry weather like we had this spring, the grass starts growing pretty quickly but it takes longer to fill up the aquifers that our wells depend on. A drought above ground might end, might even give way to flooding, while drought lingers below ground

Absent the psychological tension, technical showmanship and stylistic sleight-of-hand of “The Prestige,” this yarn from Hong Kong writer-helmer Derek Yee is unable to harmonize a mix of political intrigue and vaudevillian humor, while an excess of magic acts keeps the sterling cast too physically busy to breathe feeling into their roles. PHOENIX -- Richard Sherman might hold more than the Lombardi Trophy come Sunday.
The Seattle Seahawks cornerback is on baby watch, with his girlfriend, Ashley Moss, expected to give birth to their son over the next week.
Asked Thursday if he would consider missing Super Bowl XLIX to attend the birth, Sherman expressed confidence that his new addition will arrive at the right time.
"He's not supposed to come Sunday," Sherman said. "Obviously that'd change some things, but I think he's going to be a disciplined young man and stay in there until after the game."

Currently, foreign nationals are required to obtain pre-authorization to travel to Canada by air, and the biometric check on arrival is an extra step to confirm a person seeking admission is really the same pre-screened individual on the travel documents.
“Biometric screening has proven effective in protecting the safety and security of Canadians and the integrity of the immigration system. Systematic fingerprint verification allows border service officers to confirm a traveller’s identity,” said Immigration Department spokesperson Shannon Kerr.
“Biometric screening has also made it easier to identify known criminals at the earliest opportunity in order to prevent them from coming to Canada. It has made it more difficult for others to forge, steal or use another person’s identity to gain access to Canada,” Kerr added.
